I think the main reason this happens is the focus thing. When we are a kid, everything is new as you said - and therefore we have a tremendous amount of information getting in our brain each day making them feel longer. When you grow up and start getting used to life, your attention is way more selective. Nobody tends to wake up and analyse in details every detail in the room for example, or in the street. We know the wall is a wall so our attention is not directed onto that. Same goes for actions and basically everything - we automatise things, driving - routines - dressing - so much things we don't need to focus on anymore.
This is then amplified by other things - we spend more time in our thoughts, because we now have concerns, complex thoughts, memories etc. And time spent in one's own mind makes the time feel very very fast, it's an abstraction from the present moment. Same goes for the flow thing you described, focusing a lot and giving it all for something means making abstraction of everything else around to purely focus on one thing, which means abstraction from the present moment again, and times feels faster. And with the high tech and connected society, it's even increased since time spent in front lf screens create this effect. Therefore, as adults, we are constantly in some sort of abstraction, be it automatisms, focus or thoughts, and that's why time feels quicker.

What is completely missed here is how the brain works with routines. For the brain it is highly stressful to get new impressions every second. So it likes to order/categorize things, activities and creates routines for an easier daily process flow. For example you are driving the car to work for the last 10 hours and you know the streets by heart. Even though the people on the road may vary, you are working in a routine. I am pretty sure a lot of you have experienced the "how did i got here so fast". Another example: When you are leaving the house and you are wondering if you have locked the door. You had been in a routine again. When you are playing games, sports -> muscle memories: these are all routines. During your days you are doing most likely everyday quite similiar things so your brain will enforce routines to simplefy the data processing. So how to escape the circle of routines? Find out what routines you have and change during your daily business some of them. You are definitely going to notice that you can slow down the time a little. Time doesn't get faster as you get older. It's all about perception. Time doesn't speed up when you are older because it has not changed since you were younger. We tend to put alot more thought into other aspects of our life when we are older compared to when we are younger. When you are young you tend to be preoccupied with time where as being an adult our minds are focused on activities that distract us from the clock. It's perception. Focus on a clock for an hour and watch how slow time appears to be moving. Now focus on doing some activities for an hour and watch how fast time seems to have moved. The clock dosent speed up or slow down just because you watch it. It stays at the same pace everyday all day. I believe time speeds up for a combination of reasons.

1. Our brain has more information to process, and sort through as we get older.
- This requires more processing time and so our passing of time seems to go by faster.

2. We become more patient and better at performing meticulous tasks.
- As we get older we have a lot more meticulous, repetitive tasks to perform, and to cope with this our brains get better at passing the time, or going into cruise control.

3. Points 1 and 2, can skew our perception of time, if we let them.

4. Depending on agency all people can have a more realistic perception of time passing, a faster perception of time passing, or a slower perception of time passing.
- If you have to wait to go to the bathroom, If you're in a boring meeting or lecture and really want to get out. Time seems to go by slower than normal.
- If you're having a good time and don't want it to end, time goes by much more quickly.

- Young people correctly estimate a minute, whereas, older people overestimate a minute (giving recording of more than the actual minute.
Older people's internal sense of time is slow which makes the external/real sense of time feel fast.
- We don't just experience as it passing but also as it has passed before. These ways of looking time don't align. For example, holidays go by really quickly but when we look back at them, they last a really long time. When brain looks back it judges the duration of that vacation by the number of memories were formed. In that moment, it felt fast.
- This is the paradox of our perception of time. If you want time to go slowly, you can expose yourself to things that will slow time down but it won't be pleasant.
- Conclusion: Maybe the happiest life and the most remembered life is where time seems to really fly. As Einstein said, "Put your hand on a stove and it will feel like an hour. Sit next to a pretty girl for an hour and it will feel like a minute.

Note to self:
- Time goes faster the more energy your brain uses. But this doesn't make sense in terms of new experiences. For example, why a vacation then go by quickly? *I say this assuming that new and happy experiences use more energy.
- Repetition makes time go faster. *I guess this can also relate to previous point because repetition uses less energy*.
- If you want to decrease your sense of time, break repetition, do exciting things (uses less brain energy? can't be).

The concept in human motor behavior that our minds are constantly wanting to approach "expert mode" in tasks explains this. Think of the movie "Click" - when we become experts in something, it becomes an autonomous task/program in the brain that is executed without much thought. The more we do this, the more we "cruise" through life and, thus, the perception of time is faster. Want to have a perceived longer life? Keep learning. If we never coast on our knowledge and instead become lifelong learners, becoming "expert mode" only becomes a foundation for the next thing to learn and we will be able to continue that "slow timer" we had as kids when we were learning how everything around us works.

Familiarity reduces engagement because your past experience informs your perception and your brain recognizes elements from the experience and uses assumptions based on previously recorded data to put the pieces together without the need to process much that is new (top down processing) so you're not as present/engaged as you would be if your brain were in data gathering mode and external stimuli were entirely informing your perception (bottom up processing).

By early adulthood you've got a fair grasp on what the world is and what you can expect to encounter so are less engaged by new things because they bare similarities to things you've seen/done before, the human mind is great at automating and optimizing processes so you're not so hung up on things you've encountered dozens of times before which frees you up to engage with the truly novel.

Imagine how impossibly useless we would be if we had to consciously put one foot in front of the other, or concentrate intensely on a simple drive to work because our brain hadn't automated those actions.
A certain amount of our functions are put on autopilot and we end up consciously doing less and less as we age, i believe this is part of why time flies by as the number of novel experiences we have decreases. It's like how you can just zone out for minutes at a time while driving and not even realize you're doing it, the more repetitive your life is the less you will actually feel engaged by it and it'll just drift on by because your conscious mind isn't really having to do much.
Conversely, whenever you move house, job, enter a new relationship etc. Everything feels so much more vivid and stimulating, you're suddenly in a phase of life that is requiring you to learn and think directly about how you relate to your new situation and how best to navigate it.

Variety really is the spice of life.

Certain medications can make time appear to run more slowly for older adults.
I’m 39, I’ve been prescribed medications like Propranolol, Gabapentin & Pregabalin .

And what I’ve, noticed is that while taking medications like these, the second hand on a clock goes around extremely slowly, 1 minute can feel like almost 2 minutes.
Music sounds slower, it’s easier to to take in what someone is saying, a film feels like it lasts a very long time.

And if you take these medications for too long and then stop them, the opposite happens, a minute feels like 40 seconds.
The second hand flies around the clock.
Music feels faster, sometimes listening to someone talking to you or on TV is hard to take in because time feels sped up ..

So time perception can be altered by some prescribed medications.

Mindfulness, in my personal experience, has definitely helped to slow time back down. I hit adulthood and time sped up, so much so that my time in university feels short, and the time between moving out and my son's birth (2.25 years) feels like a literal blip - I can remember how I felt, but not much of it.

I was determined to not let time keep speeding up, and that was helped by the usual chorus of, "blink and they'll grow up" or something similar. So I've made it a point that, as much as I can, I will live in the moment, especially around my children. As a result, I feel like I spend more time with them during the day than I do at work, despite work being 8 hours and me getting maybe 4+ with my kids. I don't feel like I missed the first one's infancy, and the second one tuned me in even further.

As they grow up I'm going to have to find some other focus to keep me from losing or wasting time, because it definitely feels like it slips away when I'm not mindful, but it feels possible, at least, to my nearly middle-aged self, to stop time from speeding up.

My theory is that in addition to our brains losing their plasticity (which results in us storing less information from our environment), our experience with various stimuli so often also dulls our sensitivity to them over the years. Our brains by the time we are in our 20s have started to become highly "specialized", and while a child's brain is yet to become fully specialized and has the potential to learn and store far more information on a daily basis, a specialized brain has more filters to prevent unnecessary information from distracting us from our goals. We start taking many things for granted as well, and (especially in our 20s and 30s) have a focused mindset on "success", and lose our sense of what's going on around us. As such, we become so focused on our future (as well as our past regrets), that we fail to live "in the moment". When we do have moments of clarity, in which we forget about the daily stresses we are constantly bombarded with, this sometimes results in starting realizations, like "whoa, the last week feels like a blur". Depending on the person, that "blur" could also be a year or more. I spend a lot of time wishing I could go back to my teenage years.

You can reverse this phenomenon by living in the moment, and strategically contemplating the future and the past. Effectively you're altering your perception of time through consideration. "Time flies when you're having fun" because you're contently focused on a singular thing, thus compressing your perception of time, and things drag out when you're bored because you're focusing on anything and everything else, thus decompressing your perception of time. You want to decompress your perception of time, without being bored, mindfulness and meditation helps with this.

Temporal Memory Progression. Things are held in "perspective".  The more time you have experienced the more vast your perception and the relative measurement of time becomes, excepting novel experiences.  Novel Experiences actually help keep the brain young as well. Even more so, this dynamic effects those who "age well" and those who become "disconnected with time". Two groups are based on the continued experience of novel events. Those that do not will slowly lose touch, perceptively, with the current time and time will appear to speed up as well with less "mile markers" being added to memory with strongest memories being older expanding the effect.  This is also why becoming a parent later in life will cause most adults, who have started to see the world wear thin, to experience a renaissance as the new experiences pour in. Though it's not completely dependent on the renewal and mile markers. Over all, the greater your sum total of life the faster life does seem to go as you are measuring days against weeks, weeks against years, years against, decades, and decades against half-centuries. As such time appears to shorten as your perspective experience expands. Theoretically this would continue with age. To humans, 100 years seems a long time as only a minute few even get close to experiencing it. But should you have 300 years of life experiences you now objectively can put "century" into a bounded experiential scale. And so on.  But then again, this is a doctoral dissertation compressed into a youtube comment so, much is lost.

When I was a younger time seemed to pass slower, but of course, having less responsibilities I had no need for the concept of time. Growing older, I started having more responsibilities so I had to look at the hour more and more, being more conscious of how fast time passed.

Not only that, but in most of my childhood memories I can only find good moments, so, of course, I feel like I had all the time in the world because all I can remember is me having fun as a single memory, when in reality it's possible that I'm misremembering three days having fun as one day in my childhood, summarizing the whole experience instead of the actual time spent.

Knowing less things also made time feel less relevant. I could spend time doing anything and it wouldn't matter because that's all I knew about the world, but nowadays I know so many things I like, movies I'd like watching, places I'd like visiting and goals I'd want to achieve, that every second I spend in something is a second I'm not spending doing something different or potentially better. My seconds are more valuable nowadays than what they were when I was a kid, not because they go away faster, but because the possibilities of what I can do with these seconds grow.

An interesting twist on the previous paragraph is that when you are a kid there's no "usual". Everything is a new discovery, so you are always learning new things about everything, your house, people, nature, life, etc... so you learn so many things in such a short time, because it's such an exciting world, yet, the more you grow old, the less things are left to discover, you know everything about your surroundings, and there's few discoveries that can affect your life, so, life feels like it speeds up now that there's nothing new and everything is the same day after day after day.

Also, time moves faster for adults because we don't live in the moment as we did when we were children. As a child, your life feels infinite, and every day is often granted with fresh and new experiences. As adults, we're all forced into a pseudo-slavery in which we work through most of our alert hours, just to afford a place to live, bills, food, and our addiction of choice. In other words, most adults are on autopilot, we don't live in the moment, we phase out, and perpetually continue to do so in the passive hope that life will make some positive change, so that it may eventually become worth living in the moment once again. Sadly, I think for most of us, that time never comes..

Incidentally, that is why innocence, is reserved for children (IE: 'Childhood innocence') and is rarely spoken of in such a context when speaking about adults.

Our perception of time is simply a function of how much information we are absorbing at any given time. When you're a young child, you're constantly observing everything that you haven't seen before, but as things become routine, you no longer pay attention to things and forget doing them, making tone seem to fly by as your memory leave gaps that you don't notice, because these gaps don't negatively affect you.

But, if you're anxious, or you're actually learning and absorbing all of the info around you? Time will stretch forever.

Our brain organizes memories by reference, not by actual content. If you experience the same everyday routine it gets committed to memory as a reference to a boilerplate version of that repeating experience. Happens with people, too. I can think of at least two people (whom I know only superficially) that blur together in my mind as basically the same person.

Also, mathematically, if you're 6 years old a year is 1/6th of your entire life, while at 50 it's 1/50th, which is a much smaller number. So the older you get the smaller a year becomes for you in the grand scheme of things.

Honestly? Perception of time is just that - perception. There are less hassles when you're a kid: you get up, go to school, go home, repeat. There might be some extra stuff tossed in, like homework or extracurriculars, but otherwise, that's it.

As an adult, we have jobs, some of which last longer than school and are far more complex and stressful. We have bills to pay, domiciles to clean and care for, some cook to provide sustenance, and some of us do it all to take care of others - wives, husband, children, the elderly and disabled.

When you're young, you have far less to think about, so your mind gets to slow down and take things in more, so days feel longer.

When you're an adult, you have so much going on, some days may feel long while your mind is stressed, but once you hit a point where you can finally unwind, you realize that the week is already over. Before you realize what's happening, the month is already over.

Once you're old and able to retire, or forced to retire because your body can no longer endure the strain, does time seem to slow down again. There's no job keeping you occupied 8-12 hours a day, 4-5 days a week. Your immediate family might be gone. You only have to take care of yourself and your domicile. With less to occupy your mind, time becomes a slow march to death.

People are confusing time with memory. We’re speaking of the perception of time which is malleable and conditional. If we possessed no ability to remember it seems reasonable to conclude that we’d have no sense of time passing (hence no time). Our ability to remember is better when we are younger, additionally events we are witnessing for the first time need to be recorded in our brains. We expend energy and focus as we make those new memories making us more in the moment. That “marks” time making it more memorable. By the time we’re adults we’ve imprinted many more experiences. So what role does memory, (or do memories that need to be remembered) play in our perception of time? After all, we need memory to measure our perception of time.
Experiment- let’s test the effect of memories on perception of time. Let’s imagine our memories are physical matter, say sand. If we pour sand into a bag the more sand stays in the bag, the more the bag will weigh. But if the bag develops holes, less sand is retained, it will weigh less. Just as the duration of a year seems shorter when so many memories are lost, or so many experiences are no longer as note worthy, hence less memorable, that effects our perception of time. In reality the amount of sand poured never changed, what was retained changed given the impression of less volume. So one is left with the impression that less sand was poured since much of what should be weighed was lost through the holes. Just like the amount of time in a year doesn’t change, but it seems to as we lose memories into the ether. We thus perceive a year as shorter than we would have when younger because we once retained many more of our memories.

I'm glad we can discredit the exponential increase theory, because nobody wants to be told that it will get faster and faster until your 60s go by in like two months.

It makes sense that a year when you're 7 does not in fact go by significantly faster than when you're 5, which the theory would imply. Something of note that perhaps obscures our perception would be how, for me, my 20s seemed to go by about as fast as my 30s (too bloody fast) but the 20s felt longer looking back because ten years ago now I would have been 26 whereas ten years ago ten years ago I'd have been 16.

The life changes between 16 and 26 were far more drastic than 26 to 36, so that decade feels longer than the last because it reaches into late childhood/adolescence. I experienced some major changes between 2016 and mid 2019 whereas my life's been largely the same from mid 2019 to today, so it feels like the latter years have sped by compared to the turbulent times. As you alluded, I'd much rather live through those recent years than the ones with a series of unwanted developments, but the trade-off is the existential fear of time whizzing by.

The biggest things to slow time down that I've found are moving home, losing a loved one, changing jobs or starting a new relationship - they delineate different eras and stop it all blurring together. No doubt having a child would have this effect too, though I don't know how their seemingly rapid growth would affect things. Five years is a massive stretch in a child's life, baby to infant, junior to preteen, preteen to preadult - but from an adult's perspective, I guess it'd look like they're morphing constantly?

They really should have emphasized the last part, which is easily the most important and encompasses all the theories and thoughts in the comments. How you perceive time depends ENTIRELY on your memories. All those times you do things that are routine -- like driving your regular route to a regular job and driving the same route back -- are not novel and you won't build any interesting memories, so in hindsight it'll feel like time flew by. When you try to remember those things, you can't, because your brain never put those memories in your head, so there's a big gap in time as far as you can tell. When you're younger, there's really nothing routine. Just existing and experiencing the world is novel. When you're older, (for most people) everything becomes routine and not novel.

The times in my adult life when I was learning a lot of new things and exposing myself to novel experiences are the times that felt very slow, sometimes even comparable to how things were when I was younger. Everything else is just a blur because there are no memories of the routine stuff.

I would argue that children are in flow more often than adults and that the more moments of flow packed into our days causes the day to feel longer and richer. My theory:  when we're young and everything is new and exciting, we look forward to major events in our lives.  Little league championship game, Senior Prom, etc.  Time drags as we look forward to these events, seemingly taking forever for the event to "finally get here".  As we age, these new, novel events become fewer and farther in-between- there's less to look forward to, so time has no reason to "slow down".

I always hear people say this but I definitely feel the opposite. Time definitely seems to be dragging on slower and slower to me. I don't know how many times I will check the date expecting it to be a week or 2 ahead of the actual date. Multiple times in the last few years I was shocked to find out it wasn't a couple months later into the year than it really was. It's the weather that does it to me the most. I will think "Man how is it still hot out? Aren't we into fall yet." OR "Why is it still freezing? We have to be into spring." Then I check the date and see it's only about a month into each season.

To be fair I rarely ever have to reference the date for anything. I don't go to family gatherings or public functions. So holidays and other chronological landmarks are meaningless to me. I also chose to live my life enjoying the seemingly insignificant things like the beauty of a flower fluttering in a slight breeze, ripples from rain in a puddle, or how air currents shift around and change the shape of clouds. This was after piecing together that the recurring spots on my chest are most likely skin cancer. That and most of the men in my family dying of heart attacks before they are 60 made me realize that while rushing through life to keep up with everything, you tend to miss all those amazing little moments that you would even notice otherwise.

People with ADHD definitely have a warped perception of time, because i have a friend with ADHD. When he's bored doing something for around 20 minutes, ill ask him how much time has gone by and he full well legitimately believes like 2-3 hours pass by. But whenever he's having fun, if something occurred an hour ago, ill ask him the last time something happened and he genuinely believes maybe 10 minutes pass by. Sometimes those gaps are much farther apart then that, depending on what activity he's doing. The best way I can explain it, if you know someone with ADHD, sit them down for about 10 minutes and talk to them about something they don't care about, and then at the end, ask them how long they think that conversation lasted.

Being "engrossed in what we are doing" happens to me all the time and has for 45 of my 59 years. I'm a professional bassist and every time I sit down to practice or play a gig I have absolutely no idea how much time passes until I stop (although pain often tells me that it's been quite a while). For example:I remember at age 16 that I would practice 8 hours straight and only think that a short time (1 hour at most) had gone by. At age 32 I started playing a 6 string fretless bass and my daily practice increased quite a lot. I had practiced between 12 and 20 hours a day, with the average probably around 15 hours a day. When practicing 20 hours I realized it was a long time out of sheer exhaustion, but if it was less than about 16 hours it would seem that only about a half hour had elapsed. I actually made a point to keep track of this "time lapsed" idea, because I had always noticed it but it seemed that the older I got - that less time seemed to have passed while I was actually practicing longer hours.
Of course, now that I'm almost 60, it seems like time is flying no matter what I'm doing. Dammit!

It's simple. When you're a kid, time moves slow because your freedom is somewhat restricted, therefore, leaving you with little to nothing to do, and with even less to think about.

However, when you become an "active" adult, time seems to move faster because you have more responsibilities and things to do as an adult than when you were a kid..

On the flip side however..? Time still moves slow for adults but only when they have absolutely nothing to do, i.e. homeless people..

The saying: "time flies when you're having fun" is a great example of this. When you're busy with things that interests you, such as, romance, traveling, working a job you love, time speeds up. But if you're doing thi go in life that you do not enjoy, time seems to drag on because you actually want that unenjoyable task to hurry up and be over..

So in other words, times speeds up when life is good leaving you wanting more of that good life and vice versa. Time moves, and will always, move at the exact same speed.

It is us who do not move at the same speed so technically, it's really all about our perception of time itself, not the other way around

When you're a kid, you have a lot more "free time", so you value time less than you do when you're an adult. As an adult you understand better that you have a lot less free time. You have to work, there are obligational chunks of time used, say for house chores or maybe getting your car serviced, even just going to work.

When you are younger you don't have to worry so much about not having time to do something you want to do, because you have a lot less obligational time. But as you grow older you get more obligational time in your day, and it seems to grow continually as you age. First, it's due to maturing and the need to satisfy your responsibilities, and then as you reach retirement it's the knowledge that you don't have a lot of time left. As you start to face death, either by losing those close to you or just reaching the point where you have so much you want to do and have never done, your conscious mind starts to understand that every minute you have left is numbered. And you start to feel that you are running out of time. Once you begin to understand that everyone does die, you now see time in a bottle, it's limited. It's not just a tap you can turn on like you did as a kid, you know eventually the bottle will run out. You start to appreciate time more, you value it far as you age, this leads to time seemingly being so short.

That aging makes you feel like you've missed a lot of time in your life over the mundane, because of all the obligatory time you have had. Vacations are faster, days off blow by, because despite the fact that you have free time now, compared to the obligatory time you have, it's a much smaller amount.

An older person who has memory issues, enjoys a slower passing of time. They don't remember the obligatory time they have had, they don't remember the time they have "wasted" in their lives, so to them, it's much like a small child again. This helps to prove that the passage of time is a subconscious view of the time used in your life. When your brain can't or won't process in the moment the amount of time you have used, compared to the knowledge that it will run out, time slows down for you. But once you realize more and more that you just don't have enough time in your day, you're perception of time seems to speed up.

Since time is merely a synchronisation technique between external entities and activities if you have less going on you are less aware or driven by it...

Also it's down to the external queues you take in and internalise as time passing. Without isolating people from external stimulus before testing time passing the result is already skewed... A bird flapping it's wing, a person walking by, a car ticking over, someone breathing rate, blink rate all cues to time you unintentionally use to measure the passage of time...

It's got nothing to do with age and everything to do with perception. Someone who has every minute of their day planned feels they don't have much time, but someone with large blocks of time unoccupied feel they have plenty and even get bored...

Don't forget the influences of adrenaline and acetylcholine which messes with your perception of time too, affecting your own heart rate and nervous system which is how you perceive time in the outside world and internally...

Time flies when you have fun because the brain is encoding the memories at the expense of experiencing them. But then you remember every detail. Remembering something is almost the same as experiencing it, and when you look back on memories you are living them, imprinting new memories on them as you relive. They are like an item in a box. Take them out, feel it and experience, but in doing so you are altering it too. Time drags when you're bored because the brain does NOT want to encode uselessness, so the experience part gets the most use. You feel every second because you are forgetting as it happens. This is why you mostly forget details of mundane things.

This one is easy. Time is a human concept, not a tangible thing. When you think about how long something took, you are just looking at your memories over that period to guess the duration. As you age, your memory functions different. You could say it gets more efficient or less efficient, depending on your viewpoint. When you are old, your brain discards all the useless stuff around you or fails to log it. When you are young, your brain is a sponge, absorbing everything. When you reflect back on that moment as a child, your memory has already logged an immense amount of data that it feels like it was forever. As an adult, that same situation only has a few short but efficient data points, making it feel shorter.

This also goes along with what happens when you are afraid. Your mind starts logging everything. Time doesn't slow down, but when you reflect on it, you have LOTS of information to reflect on, and it seems like it lasted forever in your memory perception.

Aging in humans is about buildup of toxins including arterial plaque and excess body fat.  When one suddenly clears these in a relatively short period, time noticeably slows down again.  Our internal systems are recursive, linked by blood flow.  Virtually any change within us has some sort of negative feedback, and the latency of this feedback is affected by toxin buildup including in our microvascular system.  Forget DNA damage, telemeres etc, when it comes to aging, blood flow is everything and is indeed reinstatable.

Since everyone is sharing experiences, here is what happened with me and my wife. We immigrated to Canada from India about 8 years ago. We keep visiting India every couple of years. I’ve experimented with my perception of what a week’s seven days felt. I told myself for weeks that every day was Friday. After I built that mental habit, I created a paradox in time where each day felt like a journey. The immediately released benefit was the weekend that felt 300% more freeing than the previous weekdays; this in turn created a VERY long weekend. At the end of each week, I couldn’t believe how many more stories I actually created for myself, and how many different chapters I could recall I created in each time frame. The “recall” of past time is where the perception begins. Motivate the outcome of every hour, every day—without focusing on each day’s end—and you will be able to control your perception of a week’s time. It’s the beginning of a 72 week-long year you’ve created. Live long and prosper.

Your life seeming to go by faster each year has absolutely nothing to do with your age, it has to do with memory. As we age we experience less and less things that we have not already experienced. Since we have already experience something it is harder for our memory to tell the difference between one experience to the next. If there is no difference then there will be no new memories. No new memories means nothing to remember, so your mind draws a blank. Like when you try to remember last week at work, or last month, or last year, or the last decade.... So really, if you want to make your life seem to last longer then do new things to make new memories. This can include simple things like leaning something new. So just think, you will always remember reading this comment as the memory of the time you found out your life is being stolen from you hour by hour and day by day. When you are young, most everything you do is new and unique. Therefore, your mind is more focused on the experience. To a two year old a 3 hour car ride seems to take forever because the sensations associated with the experience are all new. You hang on every moment to absorb the experience.
By contrast, when you are 65 you have taken hundreds of not thousands of long trips in a car. Your mind doesn't need to absorb new data because you already have a vast library of that type info.
Basically, the passage of time is perceived to take longer when young because you are intensely focused on every moment.

My theory is that the more new experiences we have, the more observant we are and being observant slows down how you perceive it. For example, the first time you see a TV commercial, your brain will be taking in the plot, visuals, music, sound effects etc.

The second time you see the commercial you already know what's going to happen so your brain remembers most of the commercial and you skip over all the details you recognized before. Maybe you'll catch a small minute detail in the background but for the most part that tv commercial will pass by rather quickly.

Life can be like that as well. As a child, every experience is new. Every day is new, you might try a new food, or go to a new place, meet a new family member or friend. But as you get older, get into school, get a job, commute everyday, you develop a routine.

Routines are repetitive and everyday feels like that familiar commercial. You begin to glaze over the everyday occurrences and repetitive details. Your minutes can blend into hours, your days into weeks, weeks into months and ultimately months into years.

Change your surroundings. Take a different way to work, to home. Try a new restaurant or shop at a different grocery store.

It's important to travel, see new places, meet new people, and experience new things to slow down that glazed over effect.

Without even looking at the video: thanks to relativity, it in fact does speed up, thanks to gravity. Your feet experience time slightly slower than your head (it’s noticeable when you’re on a mountain top with two atomic clocks, one at sea level and one at the summit). However, at a nanotime scale, different parts of your body are experiencing slightly different timescales.

Ergo: an adult will experience time slightly faster than a child due to the height difference. The taller you are, the more pronounced the difference but again this is only measurable in nanoseconds or less (possibly even femtoseconds).

There are a lot of other factors as well, as location also plays a role in how far away from the centre of gravity you are (elevation, latitude, etc)

Without watching the video, it's relativity. When you are 5 years old, for example, a year feels like an eternity because it is equivalent to one fifth of your entire life. One year to a 50 year old feels much shorter because it represents just one 50th of your life. For a 50 year old, the relative equivalent to the 5 year old's year would be 10 years.

In other words, 1 year to a 5 yesr old is the equivalent of 10 years to a 50 year old: one fifth of the time you've been alive

With the time lapse photography I have done over the last few years I surmised that there was a slowing of this cognition with age relative to younger people ("are we there yet") giving the "Slo-Mo" effect for younger people; they are capturing a lot more frames over the same period of time relative to older people with their slower conduction rate. Both quantities; lots of frames vs. fewer frames have to be experienced at the common "Human Time Perception Rate". So lots of frames played back at "The Human Perception Rate" equal slow motion (High Speed Photography) and fewer frames played back at "The Human Perception Rate" equal speed up of time; (Time Lapse Photography). the life seems short because of routine. You wake up on morning, go to work, spend 8 hours doing something repetitive, then go home, make a diner, eat, watch some stupid tv shows and sleep. And next day the same again. And again. And again. And again. You live the most of your life on autopilot. Years by years, doing the same job, same routine at home, every day is the same, every evening is the same, nothing special, nothing interesting, nothing unexpected happens. You don't have any memories except tons of memories from a factory/office which don't differ from each other, then all the memories unite into one, into one day, one moment, because all the memories are the same and that's why one year seems like a one day or one week - because all days in a year were identical. Do you remember every particular day at your job? Every particular morning meeting? No. All the hundreds of meetings unite into one general situation in your memory. If your every day was somehow special, for example being every day on a new different place, you would remember every day and the year would seem really long to you. I remember, when I was going to high school, the years were very short. After high school, during one year I was moving from one job to another job, it was horrible, I was working for around 10 companies during one year, but that year was sooooo long. That year seemed to me like several years. Just because I was changing my life every few weeks, all the time I was experiencing something new. Now, many years later, I have a stable job, doing the same stuff every day, and the time runs so quickly, because all I do is sitting in front of computer and nothing else, and when I try to remember what happened during the last year, I see just one picture, one memory - me, sitting behind the desk. And the year is like one moment.

Hm, another possible explanation is that as you grow older you’re thinking on a larger scale in terms of time: When you’re like 5 you’re not actively thinking about things that take a long time to happen- You’re thinking of lunch, you’re thinking of when you’ll get a new toy etc. That’s like a time span of a few hours or days- possibly months.

When you’re in high school, you’re thinking of assignments you’re thinking of grades you’re thinking of possible colleges etc. That’s like a time span of a number of years.

When you have a kid, you’re probably thinking about things like saving up for their college etc. That’s a timespan of a few decades

Etc etc

And so one year possibly feels shorter and shorter because you’re just thinking on longer and longer timescales as you grow older

Great study about time! I have one more, my private theory on time: I think Quantum Theory may help to understand time. I noticed similarities between time and photons! We know that photons, when observed, they behave differently to when they are not observed.

In my theory, when time is not observed - it ‘runs’ faster! When time is observed - it slows down! Little kids, when they go to school, they often ‘count’ hours or minutes, they have many timetables, rosters, they have to live by. So they constantly observe time. Every hour they have different lesson, every lesson lasts 45 minutes, breaks are much shorter. They must observe time in order to no to get late...

As working adults we observe time much less. We now have 8 hours slots! And time starts running faster.

Retired people don’t really have to observe time! They usually have no timetables, no rosters and so - their time seems to run very fast! Or rather - runs fast!

That’s why when we go on holiday - time always runs fast! It speeds up! Why? Because we do not have to pay attention to it!

The perception changes, because people forget the past. The more you remember, the more you can look back to see how packed the past year, five years, ten years, twenty years, etc, etc really were. When I was a kid I used to practice counting down in my head to see if I could keep time with a digital clock or, say, the microwave.  I was pretty accurate.  That was decades ago.  Recently I tried doing the same thing and was way off, the seconds were counting down so much faster.  It became clear that time was moving much faster now (my perception of time, obviously).  Which means my brain slowed down, like an underclocked computer.  So makes sense that young and old people would find different movies and music appealing.  Watching high energy content as an old is like watching it at 1.25 speed.  While slower programs would be like watching it at .75 for a kid.  So I see frenetic scenes as spastic and incomprehensible while a kid would see a slow scene as painfully boring because the pacing is legitimately slower for them.

when you are young, you literally don’t know what’s going to happen next versus when you’re an adult. It’s more like novelty rather than anything else. for instance. I’m married and hav one child. Since January, all I see is Mondays, Fridays and Sundays!! Nothing changes every week. So your brain shuts it out and you’re
literally on auto pilot! When I was in my 20s and living with my parents, all I did was work Monday - Friday, and go out in weekends as a single guy, hoping for what girl I could meet etc, and 95 percent of the time, nothing happened but the weeks lasted longer!! It was the uncertainty of what I was going to do, club, meet a girl, play pool with the boys etc, that made it last!! Now I literally know what’s happening every day hence why it does so quickly!! I haven't watched this yet but I often talk about perception of time and how it is dependent on two things.
1. The uniqueness of the experience
2. The emotional impact of the experience.
So to expand on that a little.. our minds are efficiency evolved... Always finding ways to create shortcuts and measure importance... Essentially both 1 and 2 are a lot more intertwined than you realise.. as emotions are impacted more by "new" than they are something they've already experienced before.... Let me provide an example.
You're driving down a road you've never driven down before.. the road is 20 miles and takes about 30-40 minutes.
You take in the road as you're driving as well as the green rolling pastures on either side of the road.
About half way along your trip there is a stunning lake that expands off in to horizon, the sun is just in the right spot in the evening to reflect off the water greeting a dazzling display.
Your favorite song is playing on the radio as you pass the lake.. reminding you of a special time with a loved one... The whole experience is impactful so much you can't help tear up for a moment.
Now this will impact in your hippocampus.. particularly strengthened by emotional association as well as a "new experience".
See there's more here... This is the first time you've ever driven along this road sure... But you're driving to a new job at a gas station in the next town over.. it's a night shift job hence why you're driving their in the evening... And this is your first shift.
You get to work and think to yourself that was a nice drive and all but it certainly felt like a solid 40+ minutes.. really you think to yourself it felt like an hour ..
You work your job through the night... And drive home in the morning for a sleep most the day.
Your brain works away that night banking the new memories.. it takes particular care of the memory of the lake.... Because it's important, hence the emotional response.
You get up in the evening and drive to work again.
This time the drive feels less interesting... And two things happen...
A. Your mind uses almost what you'd call a de-duplication process inline with your senses... That is.. the things it's seen before, it pays "less" attention to.
Sort of like saying... "I've already seen that I don't need to process it"
And B. you're less excited.. in fact you're not really looking forward to work as it's a mundane job .. so your brain is less stimulated and thus doesn't process things in as much detail... Which makes time pass perceptibly faster...
The combination of both the fact you've already done this activity before as well as the fact you're less excited both work together to make the time pass faster.. or more so... The memories of that time as less detailed so the whole experience passes faster.
This applies to the rest of our lives.. with the things we've done before having less attention applies and making less an impact emotionally to our memories thus passing quicker .. and quicker and quicker .
On top of those things there is also the ratio of time lived over time left. .your first 10 years is 100% OF your life so far.. but the next 10 are now only 50% of your life so far...
When you're 40.. the next 10 years are now only 25% of your life lived so far...
All of these things combine together to make life speed up expedentially...

The brain is very good at hiding away irrelevant information. For instance, if you've been at your job for 3 years doing the same tasks in the same environment with the same people, your brain doesn't bother to remember every moment in clear detail. It files most of that away...kind of like hiding rows in an Excel spreadsheet. Only the unique events and experiences that your brain deems noteworthy are remembered in detail. The rest is just summarized giving you the gist of what happened. The older you are, the more information has been deemed irrelevant. Suddenly half of your life, or more, has been hidden in the Excel spreadsheet, giving you the sense that a much shorter amount of time has passed.

TLDR: Our brains are too efficient

I wish I had come across this video years ago.  I theorized that the actual reason time seems to pass faster is simply because as we get older we forget more than we remember.  And when you don't remember all those details time seems to fly by faster.  Not including fight or flight experiences, or extremely enjoyable ones.  That wasn't part of the theory at the time.  The baseline was memory being less spongy with age.

Interesting topic although two concepts are mixed. During the introduction the question is posed why a week, month or year appears to be going faster when getting older. However most of the argumentation focuses on the perception of time during its actual 'consumption', in the moment. Therefore the original question did not get answered properly in my opinion. My hypothesis is that the overall experienced time is dependent on the amount of significant events in life. Simply increase the amount of significant event and you will notice, the weeks, months and years will be going much slower again. Derek did mention it in between the lines: the amount of memories are important. Increase those, time will slow and if done in the right way, happiness increases.

Our perception of time is completely relative to how long we have been aware of time.  First off, we have to dispense with the illusion that our time is the same as t  in physics.  It's not.  Our time, or our perception of time, is based on the second law of thermodynamics.  We feel time moving "forward" because of entropy.  Now that we've established that, I will go on to support my original argument.  Since our measure of time is completely relative to how long we have been measuring it, then as we get older the percentage of our life a year takes becomes smaller.  When you are one year old then one year represents 100% of your life.  That's all of your memories, so when another year passes it feels like you just lived another lifetime.  As you get older and your collective memories grow, that passage represents less and less a percentage of your life.  A year of memories and experiences at 70 years represents 1/70th of your collective memories, so you feel it pass at a pace that is proportional to the inverse of that percentage. "... you've already lived half of the total by age 6..."

There's a moment right around that age when children "come online" in a sense, regarding not just their consciousnesses, but their self-awareness. Perception of time is very closely tied to self-awareness as a function of the stimulus feedback loop that creates consciousness. There's a reason why adults don't remember much before the age of 5/6 and why they remember virtually nothing from their toddler years. It's because the mechanisms for correlating the passage of time to distinct and descrete memories aren't fully formed yet, and necessarily so in order for the relative measure of the passage of time to not be unbearably slow for a conscious, self-aware being. We're not fully aware of each moment when we are small children, and only pockets of consciousness are present. Continuous consiousness and self-awareness manifest later on, when each moment can be experienced as a small enough fraction of the overall amount of time we've already lived. Time seems to pass faster as we age because our only metric of how fast time is passing is based on time's passing being inextricably and exclusively relative only to itself, regardless of how many devices or methods we use to objectively track it. An isolated minute may feel just as long in the moment at 65 as it did at 15 when actively and consciously aware, but relative to how many minutes have already passed, when being traversed passively, they move at two very different tempos when placed in the context of comparitive duration to overall duration at each point in time.

This is flipped backwards.  When you are young life seems fast, things change drastically day by day, week by week.  When you are older you wonder where the years are going because they all bend together.  Rarely do things change drastically like moving, or changing jobs, etc.  When you think about it this actually makes sense.  Think about a 1 day old baby.  1day is its entire life.  The next day he is twice as old.  Whatever happens that day took 1/2 its life to happen.  Same from 1 yr to 2 yr, 10 yr to 20 yr.  When you are 20 you have spent over almost 66% of your life in school.  By the time you are 30 its down to 40%, by the time you are 40 its 33%, and so on and so forth.  The point is the more days you have behind you the less overall significance any new day has compared to the total and so every day is far less important that the earlier ones.  Imagine living to be a million.  How important would you imagine a single day would be.  Not as important as that baby that was only 2 days old, thats for sure.

I explained it to my kids like this.  As your frame of reference changes, your perception of time also changes.  For example, when you're 5 years old, waiting for next Christmas takes 20% of your life.  When you turn 10, it takes only 10%.  When you turn 25, it takes only 4%.    The longer you live, the larger your frame of reference.  Things that used to take a significant fraction of your life - will later take such a small percentage that they seem to happen back-to-back....which is why buying Christmas presents begins January 1st for those of us in our 40's......because Christmas is literally only 2% of our life away.  If you subtract the time we sleep, all of these percentages are cut in half.....  It's all about the frame of reference.

The experience of time is relative. When you're having fun, it goes by quickly; when you're waiting on hold or in a line, it feels like forever. It's the same with experiences. When we're young we're constantly being exposed to new experiences, new pleople, new places, new ideas, etc. All of that is memorable and so we really take it in and it feels longer than it was. But when you're an adult living the routine with few new encounters or experiences, people to care for and a plethora of responsibilities where you almost cease to exist, the days all look and feel the same and so you can't distinguish them after a while and you lose the sense of time. It feels like you're literally just teleporting from one date to another.

Notes:
1. As we age, our internal clock seems to slow down (because our neurons speed decreases) and hence the external world seems to speed up.
2. Time seems to speed up when we are more engrossed in what we are doing. (Like on vacations)
3. New things and ideas take time to register in our brains, hence making time go slower. (because mental processing takes time)
4. Perception of time for an activity is proportional to the energy uptake by the brain for processing.
5. Being afraid or bored, makes time go slower.
6. (During reminiscence) More memories, slower time. (Because writing to disk is slower!)
7. The great paradox : (relate pt. 2 with pt. 6)
8. Put your hand on a hot stove for a minute and it seems like an hour. Sit with a pretty girl for an hour, and it seems like a minute. - Albert Einstein

Oh, slow down.  Neuron firing rate is not the same thing as conduction rate.  Conduction rate is measured as axonal or nerve conduction rate.  Nerve impulses travel via the axons which are the "rope like" projections which actually conduct the nerve impulses to their targets (other neurons, muscles, sensory impulses, etc).  And axons are surrounded by a "Jacket" of fatty acids mixed with proteins and glycosides known as Schwann cells.  And abnormal thinning of the Schwann jacket thickness or a hole in it can adversely slow down the travel of neural impulse currents just like stripping the coating from the copper wire within adversely effects electrical current traveling via the wire.   We do know that as we age, we lose brain neuron cells and the Schwann cell jackets do thin out leading to "age related" slower neural conduction.  But we also have changes in our brain chemistry with less dopamine, serotonin, epinephrine and acetylcholine which lead to profound changes in our thinking and motor (muscle not cars) control.

If I'm trying to estimate an amount of time - say, 30 seconds - I do that in a particular way. I imagine, visually, the change in angle of the second hand on a clock where the second hand moves smoothly and I have been pretty consistently good at that over the years. I am now in my 60's.
I decided that I needed a way of estimating time intervals pretty early on in my life - when I was in my teens - and so I decided to try this out.
Some people count the numbers but this uses parts of your brain that involves speech and that is not very reliable - one possible reason being that you also process sounds that you can hear and this interferes with this process although that is just a guess.
Using the angle visualisation method means that you can have a conversation with somebody at the same time and still be as reliable in the same way that you can have a conversation with somebody using an abacus without interfering with their abacus use because it uses a different part of the brain.
It would be interesting for some research into this, perhaps using MRI to see which parts of your brain are active.

We perceive time according to the time spans we have experienced at different stages of life.
When did we really become aware how long time passes in or lives? The first 18(?) years were with a developing brain.
I think we really get good grasp on how fast time passes as we come of age and early adult life and suddenly realize we are racing against the clock.
As we begin to realize we can't win against the clock we begin to more and more subconsciously ignore the passage of time for the sake of our own sanity, because we are running out of time and getting closer and closer to our last breath.
It reaches a point where years can pass and we ignored time, then occasionally something reminds us of the span of time that passed while we were busy distracting ourselves from our own mortality and we are suddenly struck, where did the years pass? You can't think about that for too long before being filled with the anxiety of facing our own demise. So what do we do? Ignore it, or go crazy.

Apparent speed up of time might be due to our mind taking less time to process and store data that are similar to the ones already in the memory bank.
Inversely, for completely new or foreign data coming in time might feel like it has slowed down as the brain will need to identify if it matches older patterns and create new allocations within the neural networks.
Over time if the 'newer' data is repeated and similar data is encountered time will speed up again.
Over many iterations through ones life, as againg occurs and the your total data set increases common patterns will emerge and the brain will become more and more adept at recognizing them and matching them to older blocks.

Something I noticed even as a kid is that if I count seconds, time passes faster. It's like it gives me some metric to anchor/ground myself with and I can speed the time instead of just floating in a sort of limbo. This made any time I was told to sit still for 5 minutes go faster, short car trips, etc. Anything I could count my way through without getting bored or losing count.

My feelings, as a person a bit shy of 4 decades, is that it's "all of the above". Any given amount of time is a smaller percentage of my whole then when I was 1/5th this age. But also, I suspect the brain slows down with age such that the temporal distance between "ticks" of my clock are greater. We measure time as the "temporal distance" between two "events", so it stands to reason that our internal clock has ticks/CPU cycles. If we have fewer cycles, we pick up less information. It's like taking a picture every second vs taking a picture every 5 seconds and then looking at them together after 2 minutes of doing so. In the first case, you have 120 pictures while in the second, you have 24. So in the second case, you catch more data, and perceive less "time" having passed.

But then there's also repetition, where things you do often become routine and seem to take less time. But this is probably ACTUALLY the brain focus argument, as things you repeat a lot you require less brainpower and focus to complete. So in this way, repetition is more "how easily can you 'autopilot' the task?", which is a brain focus/activity/energy argument.

Finally, there's the brain state, such as scared, excited/adrenaline pumping, and/or bored, each of which ALSO chemically alter our brain CPU speed, which (going back to that argument above), means a greater awareness of time since the greater speed your brain is processing, the more instants of time you record (again, the picture every second vs picture every 5 seconds discussion). Obviously that plays a role as well. Though ARGUABLY this could mean that the brain state is just an extension of the CPU argument...

Taken together, I think this explains, on the whole, what's going on and how our perception of time changes. Though I think one CAN choose to focus on the moment while they're living in it, extending enjoyable experiences. That takes a lot of mental discipline and may diminish enjoyment, though, depending on the person. So it's not always a choice between having a long perceived life or a short but enjoyable one. It's possible to have both, I think...

I was always told that the reason time seems to speed up as you get older is because when you're young, you have no memories made. Everything is new to you, so time seems to move slower so you can soak in all that information. But as you get older, since you already have memories made, your brain is constantly trying to find new things to take in. So time seems to move faster.

There is more to it than that. When very young the brain is smaller and the neuronal distances are shorter so the brain cycle rate is faster. Life is a sensory exploration experience and we are highly geared to seeking out new experiences which we process in two main ways, the purely emotional non executive sensory flow, and the executive managed selective flow (reading a book, having a conversation, etc). Both of these have different time perceptions, but compounding this is that as we age our brain cycle rate slows down making time seem to pass more quickly. Also as we age the brain transitions from all grey matter to more white matter (connections). I suspect that the brain doesn’t track activity performed by white matter (automatic subconscious) in the same way so have a different time perception.
Smaller brains cycle faster and react to sensory information much faster. Next time you are hearing the sounds of birds think about how they experience those sounds. Their ability to transmit information is massively greater than ours. There is more in a warble than just a noise.

My theory is that we experience fewer and fewer impactful moments per year and that makes it seem to speed up.
For example:
A young childs most exciting moments are arguably Christmas or third birthday. To get there they must experience 365 different events to get there. Kids tend to be day to day creatures.
As we get to school age we start living for the weekend. Well there are only 52 weekends in the year. So you have gone from having to experience 365 events to only 52.
As we get older most of us live and pay bills. The monthly Bill's only come 12 times per year.
So we went from experiencing the year day by day as a child, week by week as a school aged, and then month to month.
Just a thought but it seems to fit well in my opinion.

It's the brain's frame rate.

When you are young, you have a soft, squishy, largely empty brain. Your frame rate is high. Why not? You have all this space to write memories to, and being able to access more information is a good survival trait. Days seem endless, because our frame rate is high.

As you grow older, the brain fills up. Your frame rate reduces, as you have less space to store stuff. The result is time seems to flow faster, because your frame rate is slower.

When you are in mortal danger, it is often said that everything goes in slow motion, as adrenaline hits and you become hyper alert. Your system has driven your internal frame rate into absolute overdrive, again as a survival mechanism. The 'life flashing before your eyes' is your brain desperately categorizing all past exeriences and memories to find something that can increase the possibility of survival.

The brain's frame rate.

I’ve been driving manual transmission cars since 1977. I used to be aware of every single shift. Then one day, probably in the early 1990’s, I was at a red light. It turned green, I was driving down the road and I noticed I was in my top (5th) gear. I did not at all remember doing any of the shifting from 1st, to 2nd, etc. It was as if I started out in 5th gear and never touched the shifter. I think all of our daily life, by the time we are older, is mostly repetitious. Doing repetitious things is not noticed as much by the brain and in effect time seems to go faster.

Asking people on the street if they can guess when one minute has elapsed, and then graphing their answers based on age, is extremely flawed experiment that will provide no useful data.

The ability to measure 60 seconds at 60 BPM is something that most experienced musicians can do, and people who use short periods of time such as a minute or two in their day-to-day life of career will be able to estimate a minute much easier than someone who doesn’t work with this construct regularly.

The experiment looked like convenience sampling rather than adjusting for all of these advantages that people can have regardless of how old they are.

Anecdote, I could tell you almost exactly when one minute is elapsed, and I will be able to do so for decades to come.

One of the great myths of life is that childhood passes quickly. In fact, because time moves more slowly in Kid World--five times more slowly in a classroom on a hot afternoon, eight times more slowly on any car journey of more than five miles (rising to eighty-six times more slowly when driving across Nebraska or Pennsylvania lengthwise), and so slowly during the last week before birthdays, Christmases, and summer vacations as to be functionally immeasurable--it goes on for decades when measured in adult terms. It is adult life that is over in a twinkling.
(Bill Bryson, The Life and Times of the Thunderbolt Kid)

I have perfect pitch and photovisual memory, and can vividly remember the second hand of the clock moving by. As I aged, I had to re-learn BPMs every few years, as the world became faster. I can only estimate, but my perception of time passing, is that a second passes about 45-50% faster than it did when I was 8-10 years old. It was about 33% at age 33, and 20% at age 27. I started noticing the time changing by about 5% when I was 14-15 years old and it's kept continuing to dilate, from my point of view or bias, at a very constant and predictable rate. 100bpm to me at age 10 is 133bpm. The same goes for travelling by car. 85mph is roughly the same as travelling at 60mph at age 16. I would have to drive about 130-135mph to feel like I did driving 100mph at age 16. It's wild, I've been participating in a study about it for over 35 years with John Hopkins.

Two factors; Anticipation & Established knowledge.

Anticipation: As you're young and as you're on your way to a concert you have a lot to look forward to, the things you get to do, the people you'll meet. You're seeing the world pass by in the car as you observe everything you haven't seen before. So time goes slower.
As you get older/get back from the concert your mind is full of things to process, names of people, things that happened etc. So you're so ocupied mentally that the time seems to pass way faster.

Established knowledge: This covers why going to the same concert over years shortens the percieved time of the road-to the concert; Because you've seen the same things and have things to think about the time also goes faster.

It is also possible that time is actually changing... when we first encounter the concept of time, that becomes our baseline. If actual TIME speeds up, then when we are 5, we have a baseline of a the duration of a minute. If time keeps going faster, we could perceive 1 minute as shorter than when we were 5, but current day 5 year olds are given their baseline of a minute. That amount of "TIME" could actually be less than it was when we were 5, but they have no other reference to compare to. If time continues to speed up(at the same rate), when they get our age, they would have the same impression when comparing to 5 year olds.
Also note that clocks do not measure "time", they measure periodicy of a physically oscillating phenomenon. If TIME changes, it would do so independently of the mechanical oscillation....

You could argue that if older people do, in general, overestimate how long a minute is, they are experiencing time pass SLOWER than a younger person. If the converse was true, I can certainly imagine this being presented as "evidence" that younger people experience time slower than older people, such is what passes for a conclusion in "scientific" research.

I had a heated argument and almost lost a friend a year ago when they claimed QED on the fact that time seems to speed up as you age because of the "A unit of time forms a smaller proportion of your life as you age" thing. So what? Why does that necessarily influence your perception of time?

As someone in their early 40s, I sometimes experience now the thought that "I can't believe that was only 2 weeks ago, it seems much longer". Every time, it's because I packed more novel experience than usual in to that range of time.

I would say that the reason is because novel experience decreases, in general, as you age and when looking back at blocks of time in the past, there are less stand-out memories to get a hold of. The problem with this is that you are going to actually remember more incidents from the recent blocks than the older blocks, so if there were the same amount of novel memories in, say, 1-2 years ago that there were from 10-11 years ago, time should seem to be slowing down because you remember more from stuff from the recent block? When I think about my childhood, say from school years Sept 85-August 86, I can remember hardly anything, certainly don't remember what I thought about the passing of time back then ( not that I would have thought anything about it ), to try and make the claim that time "goes slower" now than it did then is utterly absurd.

This gives me an idea that the best way to enjoy and get the most value out of a vacation would be to film / document your experience each day. Then for one hour each evening, review a summary of what you did that day. Discussing it with the people you're on holiday with, reflecting on the things you enjoyed, giving yourselves more of a chance to commit those enjoyable things to memory and providing a structure of the holiday as a whole in your mind, so later on you aren't left wondering where all the time went and why it seemed to go by so fast. It should be much easier to recall many specific events in chronological order as well as notable associations like a meal you particularly enjoyed, or that couple you met and really got on with and were going to add on facebook. Rather than just remembering a non-specific mishmash of good times and generally feeling happy and relaxed.

I think most of this is nonsense (except the neuron firing rate part). The only important flow of time is the objective one. The illusion of time dilation and contraction is just that, an illusion. A bit of training removes that entirely. Ask any musician who's learned how to count time.

The likeliest explanation for why many people (but no, not everyone) feels things moved a lot slower when they were kids is because a major portion of childhood is actually idle time. You spend so much time waiting for adults to give you a sense of direction because you have no agency of your own. As you grow older you gain more agency and with it more responsibility. Rarely can you just stare off into the clouds and measure your awareness of a moment. Combine this with poor recollection of childhood memories and extremely imprecise vocabulary of temporal experience and you'll get a full explanation for this illusion.

tl;dr start timing yourself doing certain activities and note that time objectively flows the same way; how your attention chunks experience, on the other hand, doesn't.

My theory on this phenomenon has always been about milestones. Milestones are the emotional stakes in the ground which help us measure the march of time. So many of life’s milestones occur by the age of 25 (I’m estimating). After that, for many of us, our career and life trajectory are established. The milestones become few and far between. We fall into a sort of ground hog’s day with no milestones helping us differentiate between one week, month, or year from the previous.

There's an extension of what you're saying about focus which actually puts the whole human race on a gradual incline towards faster perception of time. Two hundred years ago it took days to get anywhere, months to get around the world, now it takes hours. And, we can see and hear people on the other side of the planet instantaneously, we can order something online and now it can even be there tomorrow, we have all of the videos and music of the internet and it's all not just available to anyone immediately but available from your pocket.

We spend so much more of our time focusing and not waiting that the whole human race's time perception is speeding up, so what does that say for our future? It could mean many great things, but there's an imbalance forming where the younger generations are going much faster. The Einstein quote circulating around the internet about a generation of idiots is fake, originating from Jeff Goldblum's character in the 1995 movie "Powder" where the phrase "technology has surpassed our humanity" was first used. Social media is doing an r/selfawarewolves on us here. There will always be a struggle because the smartest voice is often not the loudest voice, but right now we have an odd new way of working out who the loudest voice is, and we're getting flat earthers and anti vaxxers because the people who actually know what they're talking about are on social media in far fewer numbers considering they are more likely to be doing something useful instead. But we won't blindly fall into that trap, as people like you are showing others how to think critically and that is also spreading amongst the younger generations, and IMO videos like these will soon transform our systems of education

@Veritasium: There's yet another concept you didn't mention: time depends on size.
There is a strong relation between the life span and the size of an animal. The smaller your size, the faster your heart beats and the faster your life cycle. Some whales grow over 100 years old, but their heart beat is slow, their movement is slow, lots of things are slow in their life. Mice live for a few months, with a very high heart beat, and rapid movements.
When we try to catch a mouse, for the mouse our movements must appear super slow, while whales move like snails from our perspective.
Human babies have a much faster heart beat than children or adults do. Using this theory, for children time goes by much slower simply because they are significantly smaller than a grown human. Ofc, once we are fully grown, this explanation will no longer be responsible for why time moves slower, but it might explain quite a bit why for children time goes slower than it does for adults.

I like to think of our perception of time as a combination of visual perception rate and Einstein's Theory of Relativity. So people can see the world at around 60 fps. However, flies can see the world at 250 fps. But what exactly does this look like to the fly? Does the fly just process everything at bizarrely dizzying speeds in its perspective? No, cause then that information wouldn't make any sense to the fly. I think the fly would rather see the world as if time went slower by about 1/4th the speed of how people see the world. Cause then, the fly would be able to process the world more easily.

When time "speeds up" and "slows down" in our perception of the world, it would be our internal fps changing. That's because our perception of time is no longer frames per second, but rather seconds per frame. So lower fps would increase the time it takes to perceive a frame and higher fps would decrease the time it takes to perceive a frame. When we are excited, our time perception shortens as a result of raising fps. When we stagnate, our time perception lengthens as a result of lowering fps.

To explain why retrospective thought on exciting moments seems longer, that's because the result of having higher fps means having more frames in memory. Since we would perceive our memories at similar rates for different memories the one with more frames seems longer. Whereas for long lectures, there are less frames of memory which is why thinking back on it seems like it went in one ear and out the other.

Though why would excitement make it seem as if time is going faster if you want to take it all in? Why would stagnation make you experience that dull time for even longer in that moment? I believe it's less about the fps at that moment and moreso resource allocation. By pushing yourself to higher fps, you are dedicating more resources to maintaining that high fps. Whereas for stagnation, you are freeing up resources to use for other things. That being said, when you are excited, your internal thoughts don't have much wiggle room while when you've stagnated, your mind is free to wander. I believe it is that difference in mental freedom that creates the difference in time perception.

When you are excited, you place less emphasis on your inner thoughts in favor for quicker action. When you stagnate, you place more emphasis on thoughts over immediate action. The more free your thoughts are, the more time you have. The more constrained your thoughts are, the less time you have.
