When we go on holiday, the first few days seem like an eternity as we process lots of new data very quickly. But the rest of the holiday flies by as we settle into a relaxed state. The same is true in other situations as well. The four years I spent as an apprentice carpenter seemed longer than the 15 years I was in the job before moving on.

Dreams are proof that brain clock speed affects our perception of time. I woke up, looked at the time, fell asleep again and had a really long dream that went on for ages, but when I awoke, only 5 minutes had passed. The brain is in fast forward mode when we are dreaming. The world is moving at the same rate but our brains are rapidly processing data that appears to be in real time when we dream, but it's not.

Veritasium ...normally I love your content and find it extremely informative, but on this one you are wrong. The reason why time speeds up as we get older is because we think slower. We think faster when we are young. More alert. The world moves at the same rate, but we comprehend more of it when we are young. Racking up a huge volume of memories. Our biological computer clock runs at a slower rate as we age. From birth to 20 seemed like a lifetime, but going from 40 to 60 was like 10 years. The 15 years since I was an adult student at university seem less than 6 years. Time moves slower when the brain is forced to think faster.

Presenting the correct assumption, and then immediately dismissing it using invalid technique, is hilariously bad. I helped a friend in 1996 write his Master's thesis on this exact topic, and there's a very good chance that some of your background data is founded upon that work. Your misuse of a graph to show that "half" is achieved at age 6, is flawed math to say the least. You are summing progressively diminishing PERCENTAGES of static measurements over a set of assumed values with an assumed end point. That is an absolute fail. The first graph is completely valid, showing percentage of life which 1 year represents at each completed year of life. You cannot regress the "area under the curve" of a set created in that fashion and have a useful result. And instead of realizing that you were misusing the technique, you decided that it negated the argument. Again, hilariously bad. The basis of each portion of experienced time to total experienced time is only part of the overall sensation. The next most significant is novelty of experience. As your life gains routine, you are not attaching any import to those repeated moments, and they "vanish" in memory. When young, far fewer events get lost in that way as a greater portion of experience is worthy of capture in higher memory. So, when older, much more of each day is "ignored" as essentially useless to retain, causing time to seem accelerated.

Specifically, the reason is myelin. Myelin is the insulation on the axon or connection between neurons. Our body produces less and less myelin the older we get, we need lots of myelin as young kids because we desperately need to adapt to the world around us. “Struggling” is what causes cells in your brain called oligodendrocytes to insulate your neural connections with myelin. Layers of myelin affects how fast/strong/precisely neurons fire. This is also why learning things at a young age is better, and why it gets harder to learn skills as you get older.

I am convinced, as a 40-something year old person, that life's monotony and uniformity as you get older is part of the reason.  When you are young, every year is something different, you are in a different grade in school, you do different activities, and you discover new things all the time because you haven't been around that long.  Once you hit your 30's or so, for most people, things tend to be the same week after week, year after year.  Many people are in monogamous relationships.  Many have jobs where they do similar things every day, year after year.  There is no new challenge to look forward to each year.  It sounds depressing, but it is true.  I have found however, that changing jobs to one where I interact with different people every day has slowed things down a bit for me.

Do you ever get those dreams that feel so much longer(days) than the few hours you are sleeping. I think that's the same thing as being a child and experiencing time "slower" than when you are older. It has to do with how much energy you put into creating the dream fantasy just like a kid gets to imagine the possibilities of what is going to happen in the upcoming episode of his favourite show or how he will use the toy to play or what is school going to be like. Due to the fact that the adult has experienced more things in life, he chooses to use his memory to associate, compare and anticipate similar situations, whereas the child with little to no experience and only its imagination to guide it will invest more energy into creating possible outcomes of a situation. So pulling a vague memory of the top of your head makes the upcoming experience more predictable and relatable in comparison to making 10 different scenarios in your head. I am no expert by any means. Sometimes i like to day dream while listening to music and i've noticed time "feels slower" as in i get to create fantasies out of scratch so much faster than lets say living those scenarios in real life. It is basically an illusion where you fit more (imagined) experiences in the same period of time you would recall a past memory. So my advice to anyone who wants to slow down time, is to use your imagination more often. Even when you are going to eat at a similar restaurant to what you are used to avoid recalling the times you've eaten from your regular restaurant and try to imagine what new things you might experience. Even if you've seen an action movie before, try to avoid comparing the one you are about to see with it. It's hard because we've all lost the novelty in a lot of things we do but it's never too late to dream.

I once made an experiment, and got rid off my wristwatch for a couple of years. Of course, clocks are everywhere, so this did not collide with my dead on time dates, but I used them sooner and sooner. After a few months, I was able to tell the time within +/- 5 to 10 mins, without watching a watch (:-)) for a few hours, even when celebrating with friends. I kind of synchronized with other periodic phenomena, like sunlight, shadows, maybe my blood glucose level, etc. And with non-periodic time intervals, like how long this or that frequently used elevator goes, how long I have to queue up in a supermarket depending on the length of the queue and depending on the amount of their purchase, and so on. But I did not translate all this to a concrete hh:mm.ss, it is kind of internalized. Meanwhile, I bought and wear an expensive Swiss wristwatch, but I do not use it very often, for me it is kind of jewelry. But my perception of time still is accurate.

When I carried out the experiment, I was about 30, now I am about 60. My sense of time is not that sharp yet, but reliable enough to be on a string without hh:mm.ss on my wrist. Maybe because my internal adjustments to time and intervals, or call it a sense of time, are not needless anymore, but - in contrary - reinforced.

In a retrospective view of my life, I agree with your experiment with the dog: In my age, fewer things are new, and the NPY (novelties per year :-)) decreases. There may also be a reduced neuronal activity, but: For fun in Corona-times, I write to a diary, and browsing this, I found that really very much happened during the last year, but with growing life experience, it is much less significant for me, compared to similar events decades ago. Hence, its significance in my long-term memory is very poor.

It's because of the way that the neurons in our brains fire.  When we are young our neurons fire rapidly, and a lot of 'firings' happen over a period of time. We measure time by the amount of 'firings' that our brain undergoes.  A few billion firings and we feel that an hour has passed, when in fact only 15 minutes have passed.  As we age, these 'firings' slow down and we feel that only a few neuron firings have occurred over the same period of time.  The same few billion neuron firings happen and we 'feel' that an hour has passed, when in fact 4 hours has really passed by.

I don't know how to explain it. I'm 33. I have aspergers. I don't feel like time is flying. My brain continues doing its own thinking from scratch and burying my past in the sand. Using slow critical thinking, I sort of determine that the past did happen and feel like enough time went by to not blindly follow prior thought patterns and do it again from scratch. The ore recent stuff stands out more actually for me. My childhood of my first 10 years of life in fact don't stand out anymore than the rest of the stuff and maybe even less because it's longer ago. Using slow critical thinking, I feel like eons of time have passed. My present interpretation of my past is fundamentally different than what I was experiencing at the time. It's like my past is not real. By brain was doing it's own thinking and burying my past in the sand all the time with awareness of fewer details of it the longer ago it was and like it better that way. So I was surprized when others on TV said the time they were waiting to see who won the American 2020 election felt like 100 years. So I was thinking "I guess their normal habits were to feel like time was flying and now it wasn't flying so that's why they said it." It's wierd hearing other people say it's flying because I don't feel that way at all. Just a simple analogy - if you have have markers within a unit time, then that unit time will appear shorter or has passed faster. If you have less markers,  then it will appear longer. If case of "boring", there are no markers, so it appears very slow or longer. Markers are comprehensible points in time journey which helps to differentiate different time frames. Another example,  if you have visited 10 new places in a year,  it would appear the year has passed quicker than a year's you went to just 3 new places. More of them,  faster the time.

I proposed years ago that our sense of time follows the distribution of the prime numbers. This is because, as you point out, there are more novel experiences early in life. First day at school, first injury, first kiss, etc. As we age, our school days, injuries and kisses, even though they may come more frequently, simply aren't as likely to be remembered strongly. So the first instances of an experience are like the prime numbers, while the later instances of an experience are like the regular numbers: multiples or repetitions of the earlier ones. We could, in principle, test for this by seeing if novel memories come in pairs as so many primes do.

The mind clock slows down as you age and that gives you the illusion that time is speeding up.  Lets say there 500 mind clock cycles per second at age 10. When you get to 50 your mind clock cycles are at 250 per second. Lower mind clock cycles per second gives you the illusion that time is speeding up. A slower mind clock also means your thinking gets slower. It takes longer to create that thought when you are older so you appear dumber or not that sharp.

You can talk around for it, but summarised I would say conscious thinking is the main factor here...if you feel like time passes slowly, it's because you're having lots of thoughts which you are constatnly processing, so time feels slower because you were working your brain at full power for whatever period of time. If you feel time passes fast then it's because you're distracted or in routine or whatever you actually call it. When you are only reacting and not actively processing thoughts, this is when time just flies by because actually you just flow through whatever period of time. And this isn't directly related to age, it's related to work and stress. You work yourself through stress, then you will overload your brain at work and it will be exhausted when you're supposed to just relax, both are not "good" states of mind and will make you dislike the time you're in them.
I'm 26 and my time since I figured this out about 5 years ago has passed slower than it ever has...it took a while but now my brain is a solid anchor and I don't let anything stress me so I'm never exhausted. Get yourself focused on work, because any pressure from outside is basically stress, and work for yourself...or else you will get in the stress cycle. Once you are complacent or "disciplined" (not self-disciplined) enough to tolerate the stress, I'd argue philosphically, you'll have given up your normal life. And statistically speaking, around 80% of the population (in our 1st world society) become such drones.

I'm of the opinion that we perceive periods of time as a relative percent of our sum of memories and experiences.  So when you're three, a summer is 10% of your life so far.  It's a long time!  But when you're 40, that same summer is less than 1% of your life by comparison.  I think our brain has perception of time based on portion of the whole, it's one of those "soft caps" of the human brain like our primate-evolved "cap" of ~250 social connections.  1% of your life passing feels the same to us whether that 1% is a day or a month, depending on how old you are.

I have a quite good sense of rhythm and time, also I never wanted to get back to my younger years. Especially since I grew up with abusive and mentally ill parents, and aging means healing and getting better, stronger and wiser, so I have no reason to cry for the past. On the other hand, I am deeply analytic and creative, I study new languages (my native language is Hungarian), I started to learn to play the guitar, and I love to dance. My basic perception of the world is exactly the same as when I was 3-4 years old, I just have more knowledge and experience, but I never stopped looking at things as an "unformed" child. I always strive for better understanding of the world, so time passes really slowly, but full of interesting things for me, so that's why it is slow in my perception. The only time I lose my sense of time, if I am sleeping or if I have much sleep deprivation (then time crawls very painfully slowly :D ).

I completely disagree. Physiological changes in the brain due to age become the new norms. A SUDDEN surge of adrenaline will give the perception of everything slowing down, because the brain suddenly works faster. But, an I-V drip of adrenaline would not have that effect, because it constantly becomes the new norm. The perception of time passing by more quickly with age is due to us spending more time inside our heads, thinking of the past, analyzing what happened yesterday, planning what's for dinner, where you will go on vacation, the garage door you need to repair, the PTA meeting you are scheduled to attend, Sally and Bert's wedding, what you are going to buy them, and so on. While young kids spend almost 100% of their time "in the moment" adults spend less and less time in the moment, and more time analyzing the past and planning the future. So, by spending very little time in the moment-- paying attention to things-- time seems to go by more quickly, because we are observing the day-to-day, minute-by-minute, less and less.

How quickly does time go by when you are driving a car..... and probably 90% inside your head? You are driving and daydreaming, which is a light hypnotic trance. Despite you driving, you are visualizing that car you want to buy, or what you are going to make for dinner, or 1000 other things besides the passage of time, besides, the thousands of parked cars you passed, street signs, traffic lights, etc. You snap out of your trance whenever something unusual gets your attention-- a traffic light, brake lights, a deer on the road, or someone's pet in the street, and so on. But, the moment-by-moment sights are oblivious to us because we're not paying attention to them-- we are not in the moment. And, we all know that a watched pot never boils, but when we're NOT paying attention, suddenly things on the stove burn. This is why.

I can explain without watching:
As a child you have not lived very long so time relative to you is much longer than when you get older and older. For example a year to a 3 year old is 1 3rd their life but only one 30th to a 30 yo.
Another factor is sensitivity to stimulation, over time with experiences we become "numb" to certain aspects of life. Being hungry isnt so bad as an adult but for a child it can be less tolerable. You habe experiemced some things so much that they become background noise as your environment is essentially well mapped in your mind making you relax and not nearly as attentive to certain details unless you give them that attention proactively. A long ride to grandmas now feels like minutes as you not only lived a longer life but also experienced this event enough to be used to it and ignore it so that time essentially passes much quicker. When we are bored, stressed or experience something that requires more attention we have a more conscious view of our situation. Seconds suddenly feel like minutes and so on. Eventually you can become use to that situation and it will go by fairly quickly. The rate of the passage of time relative to our "feeling of time passing" is related to time and exposure and then further augmented by own condition as a whole (mind and body) to create a passing of time that is slow or fast to us but is ultimately when referenced with a neutral force like a clock is never really changing.
At the age of one day, one hour is ~4% of your life. At my age, it takes 2.5 years to get that 4%.

There is a simpler explanation.

When we are young, life changes drastically sometimes just in a few months. You go to school, a few months goes by and its a new year, then 5 months go by and its summer break, then 3 months off of summer adventures, then back to school, rinse and repeat.

This lasts obviously until you get out of high school, but then if you attend college, there is another mass of years where things change drastically every few months. New places to see, meeting new people etc.

Once you start working, especially if you stay the same job, you do the same mundane routine day after day. These days because they are not unique, are not memorable. You make no new memories. So it all gets lumped into a similar time frame. "What did you do last year Bob?. Not much, I just worked". The entire year feels the same, the next year feels the same as the last. Before you know it 10 years has gone by and you have not seen much, but yet here you are older, greyer, not as physical, extra weight etc.

Simply, we experience more when we are young, and less as we grow older. Only the independently wealthy have the real potential to live life where every few months is a new experience, meeting new people and seeing new places.

Im not sure about this "internal clock" concept.. even if there is a correlation between age and neural slowdown it doesnt mean its evidence for. Many people show even higher neural speed after brain exercise(learning) then young people. I believe there is a lifestyle or social cause that encourages reduced neural speeds.

As you age you learn new things, when you are older there is both less opportunity to learn new things, such as having specialized in a career and doing that your whole life, and less need to learn new things, such as being good at your skill enough that there is less to absorb.

In a nutshell, you think time goes faster the older you get because there is less information that your brain wants to absorb about the world or its already learnt those things. It doesnt need to store memory for something it already knows, may it just updates its neural weights a little but it doesnt need to record new time that would not show an efficiency improvement, so the brain ignores or discards chunks of time from memory out of simply trying to be efficient with new information

I always assumed it was because as I get older I have to do more routine crap. As a kid, I did all sorts of different things, and time went slow. Even in my 20s, I did a lot of travel and time was still moving really slow. But as soon as I became more settled - more routine, less travel or other things to break up the monotony - everything began to move faster.
As circumstantial evidence to support this, I point to the Coronavirus lockdown, which began - for me - mid-March and is still going now, near the end of June 2020. That is 12-13 weeks of doing nothing other than sitting at home and occasionally going to the shop for food. Everything has been extremely routine, and the time has flown by.
I can offer some advice then: don't get stuck in a rut; have some hobbies, get out and do stuff; travel to different places. Nothing speeds up time more than being on the Internet, watching YouTube videos. Do anything but that.

My theory: As you age, you have formed more memories and therefore you have more neural connections. Now if neurons fire slower and the path they have to travel is longer because there are so many more connections, it might feel like you are more in your head or your thoughts are slower. Time feels faster because we are NOT bored. Look around in your room right now, okay now look back at your phone. Which do you prefer right now for entertainment? Phone right? You can watch the most insane things with no effort but you room would take creativity and effort to make something fun out of it. And there you have it, the answer, nothing to do with God or age we'll actually kind of to do with age. As a kid we wouldn't have much so we would resort to whatever we could discover. Take those springy door stoppers for example, as a kid we'd go for hours on that silly thing. Would today you still play with that still knowing that your phone could offer so much more with 0% effort? Exactly. If you want to feel more complete in a day and not have months go by faster than ever before then start setting small, realistic goals. 40 pushups do a hobby lose or gain weight clean your room and trust me, I said trust me you feel... Great. Try to avoid any easy entertainment or you'll end up on YouTube for hours without realising the time. Promise yourself that even just once just to know the feeling of good progress, promise yourself you'll set good goals and time will feel more normal and you'll feel better. And no I'm not a boomer who hates phones and says "it's that damn phone," for every inconvenience but I'm gonna level with you. Right now "IT'S THAT GOD DAMN PHONE!" But that's just a theory, A LIFE THEORY. But you wanna know what isn't a theory and is just facts? A footballer will always feel good after he lands a goal.

And with that neurological hyperarousal, our concept of time seems dilated. I also feel that our concept of time is also apart of our aging process too.

It's pretty simple.  For a 5-year-old, one year = 1/5 of a lifetime.  For a 50-year-old, 1 year = 1/50 of a lifetime.  We can only measure our years from own own perspective of what one lifetime equals.   And that frame of reference keeps getting larger -- so time continues to become a smaller and smaller fraction.

I think its quite simple. Your demands on your 'free time' increase as you get older so your overall perception is that time/days/weeks go by faster.


Think about it; as a child you have no dependants. Your school day is short, your parents cook your meals and do everything for you. As soon as you leave education and go to work. Your commute might be longer and your working certainly will be. If you have left home then you need to cook your own meals and do your own laundry.


In your late 20s/early 30s chances are you have a partner and/or kids. Now the demands on your time increase.


In mid life chances are you still have to devote time to your family and chances are your own parents are getting elderly and may place additional strain on your free time.

I always enjoy watching Veritasium videos - very thought provoking topics. I have my own theory of time perception. I went white-water rafting once and I recall how everything slowed down as our raft went down into a deep trough on the river. It was a very exiting experience and as the raft shot up into the crest, the white-water was frothing around me in slow motion for a few very excitable seconds. I attribute this to my brain operating in overdrive as I processed all sensory inputs in a heightened state. An overclocked brain perceives time as going by slower because it processes faster. Have you ever been in an accident where everything seems to go by in slow motion? I think time appears to go faster as we age because our brains process at a slower rate but also because it has far more memory data to consult as we experience current events in our lives and this also takes time. Younger people have fewer experiences (memories) to draw on as they experience current events. I wonder if this idea has merit.

On a personal level, we each perceive time by the number of “milestones” in a day, week, month, year, decade, etc.. Milestones are basically significant (although subjective) events that are a break from the perceptual routine of our lives. The more milestones you have in any given time period, the SLOWER time appears to transpire. The less milestones you have in any given time period, the FASTER time will be perceived to have transpired. In any typical live, people will have the greater number of milestones earlier in life, then as we age these happen with less and less frequency. In our youth, time will appear to not only move slower but will be more memorable. Then in our maturity, fewer milestone (to mentally measure one event from another) will make time appear to move much faster and the routine of daily life becomes a “blur” of sameness. The perception of time when we are older is mostly an extrapolation from our memories of the past. If you did something significant a year ago or even longer and then nothing of any consequence since then, your perception will be that “it seems like it was just yesterday that it happened.”

It's actually not that hard of a concept to grasp. When you're younger you process stimuli at incredible rates thus taking in more information. When you get older reaction times are slower and you process information less quickly. Like staying busy at work, if you're busy time flies by but if you're trying to kill time it kills you instead. I remember waiting a week till my birthday felt like a year when I was 9 yet at 47 an entire year can fly by and it feels like 6 months. The sad part is when we're elderly and supposed to enjoy our twilight years that's when they go by the quickest. Ever try and talk to your Grandmother or great Grandmother and you feel you have to speak to them in slow motion? Because they can't process the info as fast as you deliver it. It's also why there should be an age limit to driving. That major delay in reaction time is deadly on the road. I've seen studies with the coloration between being elderly and being deprived of sleep. In the early stages of sleep deprivation the results are almost identical to being elderly. The reaction times fell off the face of the Earth and sometimes it would take 30 seconds to respond to stimuli. Drugs and alcohol have similar effects.

In the flowstate we experience eternity, which is timelessness. When we grow up, we get out of touch with that and constantly shift between the past and the future in our thoughts, which creates the illusory experience of 'time'. Time can only be experienced when there are 2 objects relative to each other. When we come back to just the present moment and do not hold the past and present as objects relative to each other in our consciousness, we begin to experience reality (eternity) again. We are not bound to experience time as something fleeting, something going too fast, something slipping through our fingers. We can make the choice to step out of the illusory dimension of time and experience reality again as we did as children.

The answer is much simpler. Time is relative.

When you're a kid, time is slower because you haven't fully developed your frontal lobe. The area of the brain responsible for foresight. As a kid you live in the moment and take the information as it comes to you, albeit without too much thought behind. You've yet collected enough information to give you wisdom and foresight. A young person is more reactionary than a thinker, thus time appears slower. Think how Spiderman moves so quickly and time seems to slow down.

As you get older, and with all that information you've collected throughout the years, you start to make connections to problem solve, thus you make more informed decisions. While you're processing and calculating, it tends to make time seem as if it's going faster because you are thinking more deeply about stuff. Think about software programming, where you literally zone out and then someone taps you on th shoulder and 8 hours have already passed.

One theory that I came up with is this.

When we are young we have no deadlines or obligations to meet. As we get older we have more deadlines and more obligations to meet. While we live at home we never have to worry about when the rent is due or when the car payment is due. As we move out to college and to a career now we have more deadlines to meet for school, work, and even bills to pay with due dates. As these responsibilities increase more and more the faster time goes. Once you are married and have kids now the responsibility is even more because you have meetings at schools you have kids activities to attend and so forth. So more obligations and deadlines makes time go faster. But once we reach an age of retirement when kids are grown and moved out and no job to go to and everyday is a weekend and perhaps house and cars are paid off time starts to slow down again.

On another interesting note, many years ago when I was about twelve years old I went on a camping trip with my dad and his friends. On one night I was in such an uncomfortable position that I couldn’t sleep well and the night seemed to last for ever. When I got to college and medical school when I had to study and had little time to sleep I would fall asleep in an uncomfortable position and even though I may have slept for only 3-4 hours it seemed like I slept for 6-8 hours. That’s another way to make time go slow!

I gave this some thought decades ago and came to the conclusion that this effect is fully explicable with the observation that age is inversely proportional to novelty.

Ok now for the explanation :)

Every day we come across new things, but the proportion of new things to things that are similar to those things (and experiences) that we have come across previously becomes fewer as we age, in a word there is less NOVELTY in our daily experiences.

Novelty is a huge driving force for the brain, and (amongst other things) directly affects learning, and what we dream about, and a lack of novelty will increase the perception of the speed at which time passes.

This theory is not only reasonable, but it can be demonstrated very easily. Next time you are travelling between two locations, instead of taking the known and familiar route take one that takes the same time, and is the same duration, but completely unfamiliar and as high in novelty (ensure that the scenery contains as many new things as possible, and new types of things and LOOK at them). The journey may take the same time, but your perception of how long the trip took will be very different.

Next take a long trip that you are very familiar with, but is very low in novelty - time will seem to pass very quickly and you may even find you have no recall whatsoever of what happened during the journey (you effectlvly drive on auto-pilot).

Applying what you learn from above it becomes obvious why time seems to pass quicker with age, and it even suggests a cure - move away from the familiar and increase the novelty in your life (take up new hobbies and stop doing the same things over and over like writing all those you tube comments - oops that's me :)

For myself when I was like 5-6 seemed like the time when a day seemed so packed full and so long. Around age 12-13 the day was still reasonably long, but it seemed to reduce a little. Then by your mid 20's (which I am in now), You can make a day pass like nothing at all, which is actually depressing to be honest. Though I have no qualms about reality and the degeneration of the human body, I fully accept that my brain simply is slower and less aware than it was when it was young. I am not one of these "age is just a number" people in denial.
This is the same reason a young child can master new languages easily, yet an adult brain takes decades to try to master a second language. This is because the adult brain is formed, thus new information (learning) is harder and having a young brain which is open to the magical view of the world isn't possible anymore, you are basically stuck with however your experiences shaped you and time will then keep flying faster and faster as your brain shifts closer and closer to a state of permanent death.

The silver lining is that some day in the future they will be able to manipulate chromosome division and the loss of genes and ageing, basically they will be able to maintain people at their 20-30 year old selves without ageing. Thus only accidents will result in death in that age, of course none of us right now will be alive to see this. Though future people will have brain issues though, as the brain cells unlike other body cells are not meant to die and rebuild (otherwise you would forget everything you ever knew quickly). Thus in the time where they can stop the degeneration in the rest of the body from cell division, they also have to figure out how to prolong the degeneration of brain cells which cannot be simply rebuilt. I am sure humans will figure that one out also.

But to be honest, I think the idea of having to live forever as a human is actually terrifying. I know the natural order is to eventually die, and who knows what happens after that period. No one here on earth knows.

I think you missed the biggest reason which is also the simplest reason. Awareness...of time itself. More specifically, as it relates to our daily lives. When we are children, we are practically oblivious to time. We can’t hardly wrap our minds around what a week or a month actually means in terms of duration, let alone a year. So everything just feels like forever. By the time we become adults we are soooo aware of this time thing. Everything is so calculated. When spring rolls around, we know it’s only a matter of weeks before the hot season is upon us. Then when summer hits, we know it’s only a few short months before we’re raking leaves again in the fall and so on. Everything becomes so mapped out in our heads, even subconsciously, that years just start to fly by. And this awareness only continues to build the older we get.

Dopamine seems to be intimately connected with time: people on cocaine judge a minute to have passed before it has, and people with Parkinson's disease often report that time feels like it has slowed down! This fits in with the research you mention regarding task engagement.
Also, as we get older, more and more things in our day-to-day life become habit, and as you say, energy expenditure goes down as our brain becomes more adept at doing these things without conscious effort. There's a kind of paradox here though: we do more things on autopilot as we get older, but then surely we are less engaged in those tasks and time should seem longer, but it's the opposite!

I'm 64 and I'm for the novelty idea. I remember the first electronic calculator I ever saw. That was a seriously big wow. I'd never seen anything like it. It was so weird seeing the numbers change with no apparent cause. I've always been a technophile and I've kept up with computers and tech and I read physics books (for the general reader). So maybe you see where this is going. The biggest wow moment I've ever had technologically speaking was that calculator. Everything else at least in my perception is just derivative however wonderful the newest technology is. But this holds for everything else in my life too. The older I get the fewer things I see make an impression.

I think the point of this question has to do with that remembering part. So, as people get older, they tend to do less new things. They do the same thing to keep busy because it's engaging at the moment, but thinking back on it, it wasn't really different. So, if years pass, our lives are still the same through that entire time and we didn't do much that was very memorable because it was the same as always, then it feels like time passed quickly because there's not much to measure in our memories. So, I think it's about doing novel things and also about how much our lives seem to change over the time period. When a person goes from age 5 to age 10, that person changes a lot. Life is so different. But from age 40 to 45, it could be like nothing at all happened or changed depending on the person.

One thing that changed how I perceive time was thinking in smaller units.
I recall in elementary school, I thought of time as the time until the next vacation, so units of a month or more. This time took forever.
I recall in high school, I thought of time as the time until the next weekend or deadline, so units of about a week. Time seemed to speed up.
After arriving at college, my schedule varied so much each day that I thought of time as just moving from one day to the next and how I could be most productive within the afternoon that I was working in--so units of one day. My first year of college has flown by, but when I think back on it, so much has happened that has allowed me to grow more as a person now than in previous years. Maybe it is because this is a novel experience, or it is because I am thinking about time differently and taking greater advantage of the time I have. So even though I am thinking of time in smaller units, time is passing more slowly, despite feeling fast in the moment.


On the flip side, when I want time to pass by quickly, such as when I am bored and just want an activity to end, I imagine myself at the end of the activity and think of time in units of how long it will take for the activity to be over. For example, monotonous computer work passes by much more quickly if I imagine myself having finished the task and making progress towards completing it rather than thinking in terms of the progress I am presently making on the task.

4:15


I'm surprised you didn't bring up the same idea when we drive to new places vs. places we've already been to. This furthers this idea: a 20 minute drive to a new place feels longer than the same distance to a place you visit almost every week. The same place, but a different route, may feel longer, despite being the same distance as well.


Also, in regards to 6:18, think of work. When you do a task at work that's boring, repetitive, and singular, we often feel that the time passes slowly (boredom idea). When we do a variety of tasks, it feels quick. In hindsight, the former feels like it blew past while the latter felt like a long day.


Applying this, if you want a vacation to feel long in hindsight, do a variety of things.

This agrees with my own personal hypothesis. This struck me when I was very young driving a dirt bike and some car was going way too fast down our zig-zagging dirt driveway. As soon as I saw the car, adrenaline kicked in and I noticed so much more detail and it felt like forever during the encounter. But afterwards while reflecting, I realized that at the speed we both coming at each other and the distance, it could have only taken a few seconds. As I reflected, it both felt short and long at the same time depending on how I thought about it.


After this, I hypothesized that the perceived rate of time, both immediate and reflective is mostly based on the rate of detail being noticed. As I got older, I noticed that I started to acquire routines and I had more structure time management and fewer unexpected events occurred. Things that used to be full of the unexpected was now mundane and I could go on "auto-pilot".


The exception to this was when I started to find more mental topics of interest and hyper-focus would cause time to melt away.
My verdict before watching the video: I think it's because we just become more patient as our brain matures, and learn shortcuts to make time fly by faster by keeping ourselves busy.

My take is a bit different (even if I agree that time might 'go faster' with age).


It's based on experiences ... when you are young you learn more all the time, and your brain is 'empty' so you get a higher % of new impression every day, causing your brain to spend more processing to categorize events / experiences / dreaming. As you get older you tend to spend less time doing new stuff / exciting stuff so your brain get less new impressions and hence less processing and time goes faster.

I'm 0:28 in but I stopped to say I've been thinking about this a lot since I first noticed it many years ago. I call it the Theory of Relativity. Essentially, we experience time relative to our age. So 1 year to a 2 year old is half a lifetime. That drops by 40% within 8 years. It takes another 10 years to fall 5%. Then we find our place in society and become complacent drones that take life for granted, as if another year of life is guaranteed. It's another 20 years before it halves again to 2.5% at which point you've chosen the safe job so you can afford the car, house, needy spouse, and perpetually dissatisfied children plus a yearly vacations flying around the globe only to jump back on the hedonic treadmill when you get back. By the time you're 65, you realize climate change is real and you've been screwing the planet your entire life, but you're only going to live a few more whirls around the sun anyways so instead of dedicating the rest of your miserable life to giving back, you take cruises up to Alaska thinking "I deserve it. I've never had a happy year since highschool and even that kinda sucked when I think about it." Finally at age 100, the calendar looks like hieroglyphics as your 37 millenial grandchildren are looting robot cashiers because droughts, floods, cold snaps, and heat waves caused another bumper crop for Amazon, the only company left on the planet. But at least they still have fast delivery!

I feel like the "sensation" of feeling time pass is related to making connections in our neural pathways; not necessarily causal.  Take travel to ta new location as an example:  when new pathways are made (i.e. traveling to an unfamiliar location), time is perceived as passing at a given rate.  When we return from the location (i.e. on our way back home), there are fewer new neural pathways being formed (i.e. objects we pass are familiar).  Perhaps this theory could be reinforced with an example of time passing when we daydream, too.  We think back on things that are familiar to us, so time passes quickly.  Sitting in class, however, subjects are new to us, so time passes slowly.  Making new neural connections =is related to= the perception of time passing.  Whether it is dependant on the other, on the other hand, however, I can't say.

I'm a musician with an excellent temporal sense when it is related to beats per minute. This makes it easy for me to estimate one minute with pretty good accuracy (60 beats per minute!). Having said that, I have no real time sense, and have my phone alarms set to go off at 9AM, 2PM and 5PM to help me keep track of time. Years ago when I had a corporate job, my superior wrote in my annual review that they could count on me like clockwork to be fifteen minutes late! On more than one occasion I attempted to get together with friends the next day or so, only to be told it was an important holiday like Thanksgiving. I have also noticed that as an elder, events like my birthdays seem to happen much more rapidly than they did when I was younger.
I would like to see them do experiments with musicians v non-musicians to explore the inter-relationships of temporal v chronoceptive senses.

My postulate is that perhaps our brain ignors most information from known/rutine experiences and thinks only of the same thoughts when in the same environment. I think that it all comes down to memory. The brain can more readily access certain memories which are likely to be more important, and can less readily access memories which are likely to be less important. So since something like a vacation is less stressful, and less 'important' experiences occur during in that period of time, the memories are less frequently accessible and so time during that period is perceived to have passed at a greater rate simply because the memories are more sparsely accessible. I assume that stressful events are more readily recalled than less stressful events in general.

All wrong. Time speeds up as we get older because of relativity and simple mathematics. Discounting the first 2 years of life for which memory tends to be non linear, when you are 8 years old then a year seems like an eternity because a year is 1/6 of your whole life A year represents 16.6% of your life. However when you're 58, a year represents only 1.7% of your life. Therefore the passage of time through 1.7% of your life seems much faster than it did when it represented 16.6% of your life. For every additional year the relative figure gets smaller and smaller and yet our collective memory of our lives gets correspondingly larger and larger. So the relevance of "today" is on an ever decreasing curve inverse to "yesterday". There..Done.

Another thing worth considering about age and perception of time is this: Children's logic is much simpler than an adults. That's why adults generally make wiser decisions, and are able to solve more complex problems. Because the decision making process, the logical flow that their brain grows through is much more elaborate. The processes our brains execute get develop as we get older and becomre more complex.

Now turn that analogy to a computer. Get 2 different computers with exactly the same hardware, exactly the same processing power, and run a simpler algorithm on one, and a long complex algorithm on the other. Which one will complete faster? The simpler one obviously. You could run a simple equation 5 times in the time it would take to run an equation of 5 times the complexity.

A child's brain processes simple primitive decision making alogorithms. Each thought process executes much faster than a more elaobrate developed thought process would. So a child would execute multiple thought processes in the time it would take an adult to execute the single more complex one.

If our brain's comprehension of time is based on attempting to monitor the execution of these thought processses then that would explain why "things" seem to go faster. The older you are, the more you see in the world, the more memories you have, and so the faster things seem to go past relative to how quickly you can process it all.

Up to this day I can get emotionally involved with particular time (like, I have 20 minutes before I need to check something), and at that exact time (sometimes exact to the second, sometimes with small deviation) I feel sudden sensation inside and remember what I set for myself before.

I find some of this a little confusing. As mentioned, when focused (movies, sports, games, art, etc), subjective duration is lower because we're not thinking about time, and with increased brain activity (i.e. novel experiences, 6 years old), subjective duration is higher as described by a high correlation.

But wouldn't focus or flow in many cases, like when I'm playing games seriously, increase brain activity and thus increase subjective duration? Of course that doesn't seem to be the case in reality - I still feel like the game ends in a snap - but this makes me a little uncomfortable with the provided explanation.

Perhaps the increased brain activity does increase subjective duration, but by a much smaller amount than what's lost by not paying attention to the time? Or maybe I'm wrong about flow increasing brain activity at all?

So this comment thread is basically dead, but I have my own personal observations. I've had periods late in life where a lot of dynamic change has happened, and periods where it has not. The periods of dynamic change, or as described in the video periods where I am forming new memories, always seem in hindsight AND in my perception of the time in the moment to last far longer than similar lengths of time where there is little change. I can have one year where I think "I can't believe all of this happened within only a year" only to have the next year feel like "where has this last year gone?" In my experience, it seems as though living a life where there are always new challenges and experiences leads to a fuller realization of the time that has passed. Perhaps nothing novel, but just an anecdotal account.

From Joseph Heller's 'Catch 22':
“Dunbar loved shooting skeet because he hated
every minute of it and the time passed so slowly. He had figured out
that a single hour on the skeet-shooting range with people like
Havermeyer and Appleby could be worth as much as eleven-times-seventeen
years.

“I think you’re crazy,” was the way Clevinger had responded to Dunbar’s discovery.

“Who wants to know?” Dunbar answered.

“I mean it,” Clevinger insisted.

“Who cares?” Dunbar answered.

“I really do. I’ll even go as far as to concede that life seems longer i—“

“—is longer i—“

“—is longer—IS longer? All right, is longer if it’s filled with periods of boredom and discomfort, b—“

“Guess how fast?” Dunbar said suddenly.

“Huh?”

“They go,” Dunbar explained.

“Who?”

“Years.”

“Years?”

“Years,” said Dunbar. “Years, years, years.”

“Do
you know how long a year takes when it’s going away?” Dunbar asked
Clevinger. “This long.” He snapped his fingers. “A second ago you were
stepping into college with your lungs full of fresh air. Today you’re an
old man.”

“Old?” asked Clevinger with surprise. “What are you talking about?”

“Old.”

“I’m not old.”

“You’re
inches away from death every time you go on a mission. How much older
can you be at your age? A half minute before that you were stepping into
high school, and an unhooked brassiere was as close as you ever hoped
to get to Paradise. Only a fifth of a second before that you were a
small kid with a ten-week summer vacation that lasted a hundred thousand
years and still ended too soon. Zip! They go rocketing by so fast. How
the hell else are you ever going to slow time down?” Dunbar was almost
angry when he finished.

“Well, maybe it is true,” Clevinger
conceded unwillingly in a subdued tone. Maybe a long life does have to
be filled with many unpleasant conditions if it’s to seem long. But in
that event, who wants one?”

“I do,” Dunbar told him.

“Why?” Clevinger asked.

“What else is there?”

At all ages people experience time speeding up. Thus this may be caused by cognitive processes slowing down with age, but may as well be caused by objective and universal changes for all, since the phenomenon could be a constant factor irrespective of specific individual ages. That is: that all physical processes are speeding up whilst our consciousnesses stay the same, or that our consciousnesses are slowing down whilst the laws of the physical universe has remained the same. If time is a thing of itself, then the question of whether it has sped up og slowed down depends on whether the existence of time is rooted in the physical universe or in our consciousness.

I watched another video about how our genetics could be the cause of our sleeping patterns i.e "chromotypes". As I'm a bit of a night owl thought it was an interesting subject to look further into.

I was referred to something called the Suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) which contains something called the Circadian Locomotor Output Cycles Kaput gene or 'CLOCK' gene for short. Which appears to be responsible for our bodies circadian rhythms as these genes turn on and off throughout the day regulating our sleeping pattern.

I also read that they took the SCN from one 'early riser' hamsters. And replaced them with normal average hamsters SCN. They found that the hamsters still went to sleep at the same time as before. They claim this is because our body has multiple internal clocks which keep the information given from our SCN. So it retained the the pattern from before.

Edit: The above statement is which was dictated to me from material I've read but I'm struggling to find the source material to fact check this. I kind of have a theory/hypothesis (it may be redundant to the video). As time passes I feel like the months in which I didn't do anything out of the routine passed by fast because there's not much to remember them by. Meanwhile the months in which I did something novel are remembered more strongly, and that gets a plus from the sense of "using well" my time with something different.

So I believe that old people feel that their time passes faster because they are used to living everyday, years in a row, inside the same routine (be it wake up-work-sleep or wake up-watch TV-take a walk-sleep). It gets repetitive and every day feels like a COPY of the last one. If you live like you're inside a Groundhog Day life will fly by AND you'll be bored. In this sense I kind of disagree with the video, but I may be wrong. So, I think that to live "longer" you also have to make the most of your life. Not only you'll be making the most of it but you will also remember it as if it was longer. It will have the same duration, but it will be longer because it's not the time that counts, but how you use it.

If you live 100 years doing the same routine almost every day, your life will seem short compared to someone who lived 50 years but traveled to a new place every week. Also the old argument of 1 year being a lot to a 10-year-old and 1 year being little to a 90-year-old works like that because a 90-year-old probably doesn't do much other than stay at home and watch the same TV show every night, whereas a 10-year-old finds new, novel things to do and discover every day.

I want to travel, write books, learn to play instruments, record videos, meet interesting people and exotic places. I'm sure life will "be" much longer that way than if I just followed a cut-out squared routine. And if you're reading this and you're stuck in a boring work schedule that drains the time out of your life, escape it before you regret it! Try being an entrepreneur, try mixing what you love to do with something that also makes money to support a living, you only got one life, you don't have to live it for the expectation of others, make it the most awesome, interesting life you can, instead of fitting in with what others want and wasting your time.

There are thousands of ways to spend this moment, this day you are presented with - be creative. Many times I myself fail to make the most of my day, but we shouldn't give up. Be thankful and force yourself to do something new and interesting whenever you can, create projects on the side: want to write a book? Want to explore a cave or some woods? Want to create a YouTube channel to record your good, funny times or to talk about literature, science or just games? Just do it. Make your life more than a burning candle: make it a project about constructing something to be proud of, be it memories or something external.

I remember many years ago seeing a nature/science show that plotted a graph of total heart beats against lifetime of different animals. The claim was that almost all animals have the same average of heartbeats per lifetime, which means that the difference in actual living years depends on the heart rate or the metabolism. For smaller animals usually the heart rate is fast so they only live a few years while larger animals have slower heart rates and live for several years. The exception being tortoises who although are relatively small they have really slow metabolisms and can live for hundreds of years.
The upshot of this would be that as your metabolism gets faster, you experience time in smaller slices, so you accomplish more or can move and react faster. A small spider is hard to catch because it lives with a different time frame than ours.
This got me thinking of our own experiences as children, and as +Veritasium attested, where time seemed to last for ever.
So I believe that, among other things, also metabolism plays a part in our time perception. As kids our metabolism and heart rate are faster, slowing down as we get older. Maybe metabolism somehow affects the neuron response times as well.
Another affect of this is in a tense or in a state of emergency, we are flooded with adrenaline which increases the heart rate which in turn increases the time perception so you can react faster.

How about this thing. Someone in jail gets into isolation for 3 months, 3 meals a day at regular time, no light coming in so he doesnt know day or night, but lets suppose he has a small light in there for the sake to eat his meal. So he sits there, nothing to do, bored to death (lol) days go by, everyday is the same thing, nothing changes much. And after the 3 months they open his door and he/she says, has the 3 months passed already?

So what happend is that all those "same" days have been "compressed" or forgotten because they were not worth remembering, and so he/she remembers only a couple of days of the 3 months. And the time seems to fly by.

With that logic, it is beter to live a life you will remember rather than trying to make it "feel" long.

All organs in your body work at different speeds. The secret is oppositions. When your born, our neurons spark at a spectacular rate, and a child's brain record's far more information than someone in their 40's, which is while childhood seem an eternity. The older you get, the slower your neurons spark. The slower they park, the faster time seem as your brain is collecting far less information every year. The reason why everyone notices this slow down, is because we retain the knowledge of our lives since childhood. and make unconscious introspective judgments on time.  Adrenaline or morphine is a great experiment that proves this. It speeds up the sparking of your neurons and time literally seems to slows down. So the slower they spark, the faster time seems, the faster they park the slower time seems. Another example, if you have ever been in an accident, like a car crash, or falling over. In an unconscious state of immediate survival, Your brain speeds up its neurons with adrenaline in the blink of an eye, in the moment and brain records every bit of detail as it happens. Which is why most people in accidents manage to remember every bit detail, more so than an onlooker. Its a complete misconception to believe the brain only works at one speed. Every organ in your body works at different speeds.

I suppose that an argument could be done about the evolutionary need to potentiate the learning time of youngsters in order to learn faster and enlarge the odds of survival.

Young brains and young people then happens to optimize time a lot more than older people that aren't able to have a fast curious brain thus letting time go.

May drugs function the same way. Raising your brain activity makes real time go by faster.

"Time flies when you're having fun." "A watched pot never boils." When you're active, you don't notice that time is passing; when you're inactive, time passes very slowly. ... But what is interesting is our perception of how time HAS passed, i.e., time spans in the past. When we´re in the first grade, the time between the September start of school and Christmas holidays felt like an eternity. As adults, we start shopping for Christmas in September to be sure not to run out of time. ... It seems to me (as you touched on), that novel experiences make time feel longer. So the older we get, the fewer new experiences we have, so we notice time spans less and less. The way to "extend" our time is to keep having new experiences - learning new things, traveling to new places, etc.

It is also true that as we age, our perception on the length of time decreases because we humans multiple our time instead of adding them. Like how if we see a hostile dog in a yard near a sidewalk, it seems pretty dangerous, but if we add another hostile dog, it gets twice as dangerous to walk past a sidewalk. But if there is let's say 60 dogs, that's really dangerous, but if the number turns to 61, it won't really make much of a difference even though it clearly did in the previous scenario.
Just like our life, we see time at age 2 to be twice of age 1. And 4 to be twice of age 2 and so on. so when we reach age 60, we soon realized adding another year to our age doesn't feel as much significance as it once did.

Personally I think part of time perception is related to how quickly your brain receives information. For example, if you touch your foot you feel the touch in both places the moment it happens, at least in your brain, however your brain is actually showing you the past since your foot and hand signals arrive at different times (as a result of distance traveled, google "time passes more slowly for flies"). However in a near death experience like say when you narrowly miss a car accident, you react faster because of how your brain routes the signals. Thus in general people perceive time slightly in the past, but you can perceive it closer to the present and doing so makes time pass slower.

Before even finishing this, why does nobody recognize ratios, is the question that should be asked.

1 year to a 5 year old is 20 percent of their entire life, of course that seems like a very long time. To a 30 year old, 1 year is barely over 3 percent of their entire life. If you add in the bits of their life they have no solid memories of, for example most everything before age 4, and the ratios get MUCH bigger for the child but not so much for the adult. This ratio impacts every measurable chunk of time a person experiences.

That didn’t feel like it lasted long ;) I’m curious about one thing though. How do impaired people feel about time. I mean, people who have Alzheimer disease, or memory holes. Does current time feel like forever to them since they don’t remember a large part of their past and constantly “re-discover” things ? Of course the amount of memories we have is not infinite, we do forget about meanless things to make space for relevant things, but in this case I wonder how that works. Could it be that they have less “processing power” and thus time flys by because it takes more time to process a given number of things. Is time perception related to memories at all ? If it is like so, the best way to get time to fly by is to keep doing new things you’ve never done before. Another thing to consider is how “active” you are when you perceive time. If you are running you’ll feel like each stride lasts much longer (relatively) than a single step when walking even though your cadence is higher. Could it be connected to your heart rate ? When you’re scared your heart also beats much faster, and it’s a known fact that our heart beats slower and slower at rest as we age.

Just a few random thoughts :)

Time = Change (perceived).

The more change, the denser the experience of time. Perception of time correlates to the scale of the perceiver. A second to a fly is different then a second to a human. Size only roughly correlates, the essence is the speed of transfer of information within the organism. Smaller organisms have shorter pathways, thus information typically transits throughout the whole more rapidly then a larger organism. The "internal picture" is refreshed at a more rapid rate for smaller or more active organisms. The slower the internal process, the faster the exterior world seems to move and vice versa (you can see this behavior even in the lifespan of humans from child to old age).

Two ways of perceiving time, two hemispheres of the brain. The left hemisphere marks and articulates moments mechanically, the right lives and experiences (generalizations).

Time is not a dimension apart from space. Time and space are cast upon the same coin. My hunch is that as sentience evolves, more spatial dimensions will appear to "condense" out of time and the relationship with time will also change accordingly.

Our present abilities of perception evolved in to being, and they continue to evolve. I see social consciousness as a likely pathway of extending our perceptions of space and time. In many non "woo-woo" ways we can see how social structures and behaviors mirror the organization within the bodies of living organisms. If consciousness is the exchange of information between subordinate bodies of a larger structure... is it possible that humans are evolving into a metaorganism? Is this the purpose of culture and ritual? I could go on...

I think as we get older (I'm 56) we try to get more out of time, like doing something productive while waiting for something else like the tea kettle, or the computer to start up and this makes the time spent on the 2nd activity and the time waited for the 1st both seem to go by faster. If 5 minutes seems like a long time to wait for the computer to start up, it will seem like a blink if you spend that 5 minutes raking leaves.

The other side of the vacation effect (fast while it's happening, but remembered as a long time) is being in jail, specifically prison. Every single day is the same, meals are indistinguishable, and novel events are very rare, making the day go by at a glacial pace. But when you get out, after 5 years, standing outside with no distinct memories at all, it seems like the time went by very quickly, almost as if the world outside was moving slower while you raced ahead, doing nothing, accomplishing nothing except changing your age. I don't recommend it.

yknow its funny my dad mentioned the same idea to me offhandedly once. he compared the human brain's perception of time to a computer processor's "refresh rate." he said that when you're younger your refresh rate is higher, meaning you store more moments in your memory, and as you get older the brain's refresh rate slows down, meaning less moments get registered by your brain. It's like frames of a video. more data is used by 60fps footage than 30fps footage because, duh, its twice as many images. as you age you go from 60fps to 30fps and there's less data to call back to. pretty clever imo.

While it does seem that large blocks of time pass much much faster as one gets older (E.G. it feels like an entire year flies by, while it took forever as a kid in school) I've found an easy way to break the illusion: think back to what you were doing at previous points in your life.  For instance, right now I might notice the date and think to myself "Wow, I can't believe a month and a half has already passed this year!"  To fix that, I'll just think back to what I was doing on New Year's Eve and how long ago that feels.  In the process I usually kind of rapid fire remember some of the things I did between now and then and... yeah.  It does feel like a good chunk of time has actually passed.  Thinking back to autumn and then summer... that actually feels like a really really long time ago.  Not so different than when I was a child.

I've been experimenting on this "Time Illusion" for a long time, and I found that you can also use reverse psychology things if you want it to last long, but you should really think that the reverse is actually your aim and not just fooling yourself. eg. You want your TV show to come on the TV, but the show your watching takes a long time to end. Don't think that you can't wait for your TV show, and time can go past faster. You can also try thinking slowly or faster then time can also go faster or slower.

I would also argue that the way we perceive the past and future is logarithmic. For example, the last week has been super busy, but the last year feels far less when you think about it.

Furthermore, logarithmic thinking permeates the fundamentals of perception in a global way. All perception is affected by logarithmic thinking.. We think 2x 25 watt speakers is double the sound, but the way our ears actually perceive sound isn't additive/linear We're socialised being taught to understand the world additively, but humans naturally go logarithmic. Studies of non-western children are evidence for this.

Logarithmic thinking is an excellent ecologically rational heuristic, though it may seem irrational. It's far more useful to be able to quickly perceive 2 lions as double worse than one, but irrational/pointless if we knew 78 lions were in front rather than 78.

Hi Derek, thanks for your video. You got one thing right - that the feeling of "time" indeed depends on perception. But, in reality, time does not exist, in other words - it is not a physical entity. All that "time" does is to sequence changes and compare their speeds. Change is the only real thing that you can measure, whether it is the arrow of the wristwatch or the electron transitions in an atomic clock. Let me know if you want to have a chat about it, I have a small article on this. Maybe you can make another video. This realization helped me a lot to have a better understanding of life and nature. Cheers :)

I've always wondered about the perception of time by other creatures, like how a fly can react to your attempt to swat it, and change directions several times before you even notice it's moved--it certainly seems to be living with a second seeming much longer to it, and therefore time as slower than the scale at which we perceive it.

On the other end, plants viewed in time-lapse seem to move and grow on a totally different time-scale than the animals buzzing with activity around them, so could you say that their chemical processing is 'perceiving' time as much faster?

If you really want to change your perception of time, don't randomly change things grasping at straws by skydiving and watching The Babadook, that's pretty random. Just adjust and understand what you focus on, and why.

With regards to the perception of time when we are afraid. I feel it could be due to primal instinct which allows us to perceive our surroundings slower when scared, allowing us to react in a timely manner to external threats.

For example, if we are being stalked by a dangerous spider, our brain slows down the perception of time so we can see its movements and avoid it effectively. If it all happened in a blur, the spider would have already attacked and we would be dead from its venomous bite.

(Premise notice: the following is based on a Biblical perspective... if you don't agree, that's your privilege, but it does not discredit the beliefs of others... please don't flame.)

I've always thought perceived time was not related as a ratio of a (unit of time) compared to our own age, but rather our age versus the "age of time" (from a creationist perspective). Many people believe "time" only exists as a dimension of 'this' existence... a plane/dimension of existence that was created for mortal beings... to "define" mortality, apart from immortality. (God see's all things at once, so he exists "outside" of what we know as "time")

Gen 1:1 marks the "beginning" of time... "In the Beginning..." the very word "beginning" relates directly to "time"... a point of demarcation between the timeless nature of God, and the timed nature of creation.

If creation happened (as many Biblical scholars would estimate) around 5,000 years ago, then a 5 year old has only experienced 0.1% of all of elapsed time. To a 50 year old, his/her lifespan now accounts for 1% of all time - . At 100 years old, that increases to 2% of all time. The "area under the curve" would seem to be closer to how we "think" the passage of time changes as we age.

+Veritasium One of the biggest misconceptions about "the perception of time" is that it is being perceived by the "Now" part of thinking in your brain.  In reality, the perception of time is ALWAYS taking part as a reference to a previous point in memory.  Think about it this way, when you perceive 1 second of elapsed time, you are internally comparing the "count" from a past memory till now.  So if the situation you are in requires a heightened sense of awareness (like being scared of the spider in front of you), your senses record MUCH more information about every second of that time, and thus in memory, more information equates to more time spent (Lasts longer).  On the other hand, if you do something you enjoy, your feeling of enjoyment is fleeting, and time is remembered shorter.  Playing a basketball game takes an hour, with maybe 5 minutes of good feelings scoring the point, making the play or winning at the end.  Those 5 minutes are what you remember, your brain equates that remembered time to the passage of an hour and it appears to just fly along.

22 seconds in...and my answer is that the phenomenon is real, relative and proportional. The feeling that time is speeding up occurs because the proportion of your life that any arbitrary unit of time(let's say 1 year)represents constantly diminishes the longer that you live. At 4 years and additional year is 25% of your life, while at 40 an additional year of life only represents 2.5% of your lifetime(10x less when you are 10x older). Make sense ? It does to me...

You raise an interesting point about doing interesting new vs boring repetitive things though.
The boring feels to take longer in the moment but when remembered there is almost nothing noteworthy to remember and it feels short and empty.
And the interesting/exciting feels to take shorter in the moment, but when remembered feels like longer because more things are worth remembering, even though they took place in a relatively short time. We usually associate lots of new events with long times. So a trip to an entirely new place is going to hypercharge and trick that association.
So all in all, I think it's best to invest in having lots of noteworthy memories in the end, which means doing loads of interesting things that seem to flash by faster, but gives you more material to reflect on after.

I've thought about this topic a lot lately. It's all perception. It's like taking a long drive. The first couple times you drive it it seems like it takes forever, but as you do it more and more you start to break it down into intervals marked by land marks or towns or what have you, and your drive starts to feel quicker, because you are focused on the sections instead of the whole drive. Life is the same way. Especially as adults, our lives are broken into intervals  (our normal work weeks) marked by our days off. Our weeks blur because we are focused on our time away from work. Our weeks, months, and years seem to fly by, because we are focused on those couple days of the week where we can have fun, and the monotonous work days seem to blur into one chunk which in turn makes it seem like time is moving faster.

Flow experiences are a really interesting. It is discussed in many subjects. I actually did some research for medial flow moments where that phenomenon is often referred to as presence or immersion. Related to media it describes not only the mental state of high concentration but also the impression of being somewhere else ore being part of a story or that something is around you. So that flow moment during media consumption can give you the feeling to fully immerse into the medium and lets you forget for the duration of that experience that you are actually consuming a medium - it is the illusion of non-mediation. This topic is often discussed with virtual realities. And there are so many interesting questions to it: Where am I? What belongs to me? Where is my center? What is an illusion? Could the Matrix work?
Let me know if you’d like to go deeper into that topic. Greetings from Germany.

Afaik, it also has something to do with efficiency. Consciously remembering every single moment in our lives would be a tremendous effort for our brain, so it uses archetypes and only elaborates on differences. For example, most mornings tend to be the same, you get up, brush teeth, make coffee, eat breakfast, go to work. It would be useless to remember every single instance of that. Instead, we remember when a thing went drastically different, as described in the video, when we have to process new information. The morning you read that Bowie died, the one when you forgot to set the alarm, the one when your microwave went on the fritz. If none of that happens, we don't feel singular instances anymore, days meld into a timeless mass. Therefore, it is in our greatest interest to meet new people, learn new things, try new food and experience a vast array of emotions, so that we can make the most of our time.

“Dunbar loved shooting skeet because he hated every minute of it and the time passed so slowly. He had figured out that a single hour on the skeet-shooting range with people like Havermeyer and Appleby could be worth as much as eleven-times-seventeen years.

“I think you’re crazy,” was the way Clevinger had responded to Dunbar’s discovery.

“Who wants to know?” Dunbar answered.

“I mean it,” Clevinger insisted.

“Who cares?” Dunbar answered.

“I really do. I’ll even go as far as to concede that life seems longer i—“

“—is longer i—“

“—is longer—IS longer? All right, is longer if it’s filled with periods of boredom and discomfort, b—“

“Guess how fast?” Dunbar said suddenly.

“Huh?”

“They go,” Dunbar explained.

“Who?”

“Years.”

“Years?”

“Years,” said Dunbar. “Years, years, years.”

“Do you know how long a year takes when it’s going away?” Dunbar asked Clevinger. “This long.” He snapped his fingers. “A second ago you were stepping into college with your lungs full of fresh air. Today you’re an old man.”

“Old?” asked Clevinger with surprise. “What are you talking about?”

“Old.”

“I’m not old.”

“You’re inches away from death every time you go on a mission. How much older can you be at your age? A half minute before that you were stepping into high school, and an unhooked brassiere was as close as you ever hoped to get to Paradise. Only a fifth of a second before that you were a small kid with a ten-week summer vacation that lasted a hundred thousand years and still ended too soon. Zip! They go rocketing by so fast. How the hell else are you ever going to slow time down?” Dunbar was almost angry when he finished.

“Well, maybe it is true,” Clevinger conceded unwillingly in a subdued tone. Maybe a long life does have to be filled with many unpleasant conditions if it’s to seem long. But in that event, who wants one?”

“I do,” Dunbar told him.

“Why?” Clevinger asked.

“What else is there?”


― Joseph Heller, Catch-22

i have had this theory for a while. I think that time is perceived as a combination of two things - 1)integration of sensory inputs 2)formation of short term memories. If my theory is correct, then as we get older our ability to form short term memory suffers, and thus we overestimate our perception as a compensatory mechanism..
for the part about the dog, i think that can also be explained by my theory. The input that is constantly shown has neural connections already formed for it and it is much easier to recall as a short term memory. The novel input is much harder to recall, so it appears as though it lasted longer.
